title: long-covid-some-days-cant-even-lift-cup-mouth
story: When the first wave of Covid- swept across Scotland in March , Tracey Binnie was among those struck down with the virus.Mrs Binnie, who lives in the town with her husband and teenage daughter, said: “Breathing was really dficult, I was coughing a lot, the fatigue was really bad. I had headaches.“It took  to  days for the initial infection to ease.“I started feeling better, then a few weeks later I just crashed.“I remember waking up one morning and my body was just so tired, I couldn’t move. I thought: ‘That isn’t right.’”Over the following weeks, Mrs Binnie continued to struggle.She said: “Stairs in the house became a real challenge. I was so fatigued and breathless that getting up and down them just wasn’t an option after a while.“I spoke to my GP and they said: ‘OK, you possibly have post-viral fatigue. That normally takes around three months to clear up – come back to usyou’re not feeling better in three months.’“Obviously, things didn’t get any better so I phoned them back.“By that point we were starting to realise that there was something more to this Covid infection for some people.”Before Covid, Mrs Binnie, now , had been preparing for a new le after finishing her contract with Citizens Advice Scotland and launching a full-time pet-sitting business.She said: “It was going really well, but I was self-employed for around two weeks before I got sick.“My old le is gone.“It’s taken me a long time to adjust to the new normal.“I really miss going on long walks with the dogs. I’ve always been quite an outdoorsy person, but I really can’t do any of that without ending up in bed for two weeks after a day out at the seaside.“I’m living a new le. My husband has become my carer. I’m not capable of doing basic things like housework.“My GP has been fantastic but, for others, unfortunately there’s still a lot of gaslighting and disbelief going on.”She describes the fatigue as “crippling”.“It’s like a burning sensation in your muscles,” she said.“Some days I can’t even lt a cup to my mouth because I’m so tired. I’ve never experienced anything like this fatigue before.“Even a simple act like going to make a cup of tea, I’d have to rest for half an hour. Trying to get people to understand that is very, very dficult.“There is a dference between ‘I’m tired, I’ve had a busy day’ and ‘I’m so tired I can’t even move my legs’.”

title: new-setts-dunbar-high-street-delayed-council-struggles-source-materials
story: Temporary tarmac infill repairs were made in April last year on the setts – the small cobble-like materials between the slabs and the kerbs – on Dunbar High Street.However, a permanent repair is proving dficult as East Lothian Council attempts to source setts from Spain and Portugal.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: “The council doesn’t hold a stock of Portuguese setts mm x mm used within the footway areas on High Street, Dunbar.“Therefore, in order to make the defective areas safe, bituminous material has been used in small areas.“The council and area partnership are in discussions about a range of improvements within High Street and it’s hoped an order for replacement setts will be placed in due course.”

title: haddington-artist-opens-new-exhibition-inspired-pandemic
story: Award-winning artist Kate Henderson continued working throughout the coronavirus pandemic.Now her latest exhibition – On Reflection – has opened at Doubtfire Gallery in Edinburgh.The Haddington artist, who is known for her vibrant, colourful paintings and stained glass, said: “My work has developed from my experience during the pandemic, being at home with my family.“I was fortunate that I had a good experience and no hardship or illness.“It gave me time to develop and reflect on my drawing and mixed media work, which I based on the trees around my home and watching them move into the dferent seasons.“My glass work is augmented by some bright colour Edinburgh drawings based on the architecture of the city.”The artist trained in stained glass at Edinburgh College of Art in the early s and has since built up a ied portfolio of commissioned stained glass for public and private buildings throughout Scotland and Europe.She was also chair of the Scottish Glass Society from  to .The latest exhibition in the Capital runs until March .Kate added: “I’m interested in creating pieces that explore the fragility of glass working into the surface as well as the edges to expose the vulnerability of the material.“Over the years I have developed a painterly approach to both my painting and glass work.“I feel that the relationship between my glass and painting continues to strengthen and develop, influencing the mark-making in each discipline.”

title: new-tenants-residents-group-musselburgh-hold-open-meeting
story: The discussion takes place on Monday at pm on Zoom.Members of the community are invited to join the meeting to progress a Fisherrow Links Tenants and Residents Association in a bid to work together to tackle local issues.Tenants and residents can have their say on what happens in the area.For more information, contact Sue at scairns@tis.org.uk

title: paul-mclennan-msp-column-russian-invasion-sent-shockwaves-across-scotland
story: Condemned in the strongest terms by all at Holyrood and all at Westminster, Putin’s military aggression in Ukraine has sent shockwaves across Scotland.Older East Lothian residents remember the Cold War, Soviet tanks rolling into Hungaryand later crushing the Prague Spring .For the young, recent days have been a lesson in European history as Putin’s imperialist delusional invasion re-creates scenes belonging to the fascist threats of the s. Ukrainian refugees fleeing war are not what Neville Chamberlain dismissed in  as people "in a faraway country, of whom we know nothing": in , they are modern Europeans, just like us.Thanks to Scotland’s EU membership, East Lothian attracted citizens from across central and eastern Europe. Building new lives in Scotland, thousands from Ukraine, Poland, Slovakia, Romania, Hungary and the Baltic States lived alongside us, contributed to the economy, and voted in elections. It will be shamingthe Brexit that Scotland rejected has not only caused countless former neighbours to leave the UK but now leaves them in immense peril at the hands of Putin.I’m confident that East Lothian residents will express solidarity with Ukraine, which, like other peaceful European democracies, wants free and fair elections underpinning its right to sovereignty, identity and self-determination, all civic values that we share.Following the example of Poland, East Lothian should again be offering humanitarian assistance for refugees, as the county did in the past for Bosnians, Kosovans and more recently Afghans and Syrians.At Holyrood, I’ll want to see Russian ships banned from the Forth and additional pressures put on energy and other companies whose profits have soared during the pandemic to deliver effective measures to mitigate financial impacts from Putin’s war.I’ll seek assurances that East Lothian is free from the billions in Russian ‘dirty money’ invested in thousands of multi-million-pound properties across the UK.Finally, I hope we all pray for the families of those affected here in East Lothian and Scotland, but especially for those in Ukraine.

title: haddington-music-school-goes-sale-decade
story: Lamp House Music celebrates its th birthday next month, having provided thousands of hours of music lessons to people of all ages.The facility, based in Haddington, has also run youth music projects, hosted band rehearsals for professional and amateur musicians, and pupil concerts.Now Roz and Callum Maguire, who live in the town, have decided to step away from the business.They said: “Lamp House Music has proved its worth – in its first decade it’s become a successful and profitable business, immensely valued in the community and appreciated by all those who have been involved.“We’ve loved every minute, made so many friends and happy memories, but we feel that it’s perfect timing for a new owner to take Lamp House Music into its next decade!”The couple stressed that the move was not related to the coronavirus pandemic but due to increasing responsibilities concerning elderly parents.Roz told the Courier they would miss the business on the town’s Station Yard.She said: “Whilst we have announced the sale of the business, Lamp House Music will continue to run as it always has – all of our pupils will still be taking their music lessons and musicians enjoying their band rehearsals.“I think people are starting to feel more comfortable about venturing out, and getting back into a routine, exploring their hobbies and interests, so we are looking forward to welcoming new pupils and families moved to the area in recent years.“Playing a musical instrument is great for the heart, head and soul – and there’s no better place than Lamp House Music for that learning experience – a place you can relax, make new friends and learn an amazing skill, at any age.”The building has been professionally soundproofed, and offers three teaching and rehearsal rooms.The business will be sold as a going concern, with all musical equipment, fixtures and fittings, and stock included.Roz was hopeful that the new owners would continue making music in the venue.She said: “We are hoping to find people that are passionate about music, care about music in the community and value the power music can bring to people’s lives.“I think what has really been the biggest thing to take away for me over the whole time is seeing a young person totally lacking in confidence, nervous and maybe a bit low and over the course of a few lessons, or even one lesson, they come out absolutely bouncing it’s absolutely lovely.“The kids start off really quiet, really timid, not a peep comes from them and then slowly but surely you get to know them, they get to know you and they tend to be the ones that don’t stop talking!”A long-term lease is available. For details, go to www.centralbusinesssales

title: dunbar-rnli-co-op-team-raise-money
story: Dunbar RNLI has teamed up with the town’s two Co-op stores to raise money.Generous Co-op customers who use their membership card will donate to the charity every time they make a purchase.When shoppers buy Co-op products, two pence for every £ spent goes to support local causes, including the Dunbar leboat.Veronica Davies, chairperson of Dunbar RNLI fundraising committee, said: “We are absolutely delighted to have been chosen as one of the Dunbar Co-op’s local causes.“This initiative will bring in much-needed income which will go towards running our leboats, training our crews and providing our crews with the best kit and equipment.“This will in turn enable Dunbar Leboat Station to continue to provide   lesaving capability for the community and save lives at sea.”Sarah Purvis, manager of the Countess Crescent store, and Stuart Cameron, manager of the shop on High Street, said that Dunbar RNLI was already benefitting from being one of their chosen charities.Sarah said: “So far this year, just by using the membership card in store, loyal customers have raised £ for the leboats. By becoming a member you also earn rewards for yourself to spend in store.”For more information, go to coop membership or pop into the Co-op.

title: tranent-medical-practice-temporary-emergency-service
story: Tranent Medical Practice, on Loch Road, will reduce its services this morning due to a shortage of staff.In a statement, a spokesperson said: "Unfortunately, we are experiencing signicant staff shortages due to sickness."As a consequence, we can only provide emergency medical care at this time."Please only contact the surgeryyou have an immediate medical need."

title: tescos-f-f-announce-25-per-cent-off-sale-tesco-clubcard-users-week
story: The deals are exclusive to Tesco Clubcard users with bargain prices up for grabs.The  per cent off sale will begin on Thursday  March and will run until Sunday  March, according to Extreme Couponing and Bargains UK.The Facebook group has amassed a . million members with people sharing the best bargains to be found in the UK.A group member posted: “Just to let you all know…Tesco have a % off event starting this coming THURSDAY th MARCH.“% off ALL FF .“This Event will run from Thursday  March Week  to Sunday  March.“Happy shopping.”The post has attracted more than , comments as bargain hunters tag friends and family.The sale is a regular occurrence throughout the year and is one of the most popular events held by the supermarket giant.The sale includes all clothing, shoes, accessories, underwear, school unorm, and even Pyjamas.The last % off promotions from Tesco’s FF coincided with Valentine’s Day in February.

title: pictures-county-schoolchildren-celebrate-world-book-day
story: From Willy Wonka and his trusty Oompa Loompas to the Mad Hatter from Alice in Wonderland, the costumes donned by staff and students ranged from classic literary figures to characters from hit books.Hundreds of county children dressed up as their favourite book characters in a worldwide celebration of books and reading on the th anniversary of World Book Day.Other costumes included characters from J.K Rowlings Harry Potter, Judith Kerrs The Tiger Who Came To Tea and the Dr Seuss classic Cat In The Hat.

title: torness-power-station-closure-playing-peoples-livelihoods
story: The station, south-east of Dunbar, employs more than  people, with a further  contractors.However, it will close its doors in  – two years earlier than previously forecast.Decommissioning work will take place but Craig Hoy, South Scotland MSP, has called for more to be done and for the SNP-Green coalition to drop its opposition to nuclear energy.Mr Hoy led a debate in the Scottish Parliament about the planned closure of the station, which started generating power in .In his speech, he highlighted the number of jobs created through the EDF station, as well as its impact on the local and national economy.He said: “The eventual closure of the present reactors at Torness is inevitable but I do not accept that the end of the nuclear sector in Scotland is inevitable.”Speaking after the debate, which was also attended by East Lothian MSP Paul McLennan and fellow South Scotland MSP Martin Whitfield, Mr Hoy said: “Torness has been at the heart of the local economy and local communities in East Lothian for decades and has provided secure high-skilled employment for hundreds of local workers.“Future generations could well miss out on job opportunities with the SNP-Green coalition remaining fully opposed to new nuclear energy.”A Scottish Government spokesperson said: “Torness, its operators, and in particular the workforces have played an important role in supporting Scotland’s energy requirements for years."We do, however, remain clear in our opposition to the building of new nuclear power plants in Scotland under current technologies.“Signicant growth in renewables, storage, hydrogen and carbon capture provide the best pathway to net zero by .“Our National Just Transition Planning framework sets out the consistent, ambitious approach we will take to developing transition plans.”

title: taylor-wimpey-announces-149-new-homes-built-wallyford
story: The properties, off Futures Way, will be launched for sale later this month as phase two of the development at the company’s Ravensheugh site, offering two, three and four-bedroom homes.There are a few remaining properties left to sell and complete from phase one of the plan, which saw  homes being built.The wider St Clements Wells masterplan has seen a new Wallyford Primary School opened at Futures Way, while a new secondary school is currently being built.A local centre and community woodland, along with new foot and cycle connections to Wallyford and the village’s train station, are also proposed.East Lothian Council, as the roads authority, has taken over the main spine road through the development.This, a Taylor Wimpey spokesperson said, signalled the delivery of “a key piece” of the masterplan, providing accessibility into and around the development for residents, as well as its connectivity to the wider community.Kirsty McGill, sales and marketing director at Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: “We are delighted to confirm that our first release of new homes in phase two will launch for sale on Saturday, March .”Kirsty McGill, sales and marketing director at Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, added: "Following the popularity of our new homes in phase one of Ravensheugh, we are delighted to confirm that our first release of new homes in phase two will launch for sale on Saturday, March , ."She said this will allow the company to continue to provide new homes for buyers looking to make their move to a new home this year.

title: study-programme-pair-off-oxford
story: Lewis Miller, from Longniddry, and Thomas Jeffrey, of North Berwick, were among  county students who took part in a week’s worth of rigorous assessments and social activities at the university in .The programme is run by East Lothian Council’s employability service, East Lothian Works, and the university’s Exeter College and St Benet’s Hall, to give prospective students a taste of le there.Lewis, an S pupil at Preston Lodge High School, has now successfully applied to read ancient and modern history at Christchurch College, and says the programme made the idea of attending Oxford much more achievable.He said: “Not only was the week engaging and enjoyable, it also made Oxford seem like a normal, achievable place for all of us.“I don’t think I would have applied without it.”Thomas, in S at North Berwick High School, has been accepted to read politics, philosophy and economics at Corpus Christi College.He said: “I wouldn’t have even thought of applying to such an institution had I not been told to apply for the programme in the first place and I really look forward to providing as much help and support as needed for future generations using the programme.”Councillor Fiona Dugdale, cabinet spokesperson for education, congratulated the boys on their achievement and commented on the success of the programme.She said: “I’d like to congratulate Lewis and Thomas on securing places at Oxford.“The partnership between East Lothian Council and the University of Oxford is unique and it’s great to see it flourishing.“I’m delighted to hear Lewis and Thomas had such a positive and beneficial experience as part of the first programme in , and that this has inspired them to apply to become Oxford students.“We are keen to see the partnership continue as a success, offering signicant educational and social opportunities. It provides young people from East Lothian with the chance to sample university le and helps build the confidence to apply for a place. I’d like to thank everyone involved in the programme so far.”Professor Sir Rick Trainor, head of Exeter College, said: “Exeter is committed to encouraging more applications from groups underrepresented at Oxford, including students from Scotland, and Exeter’s study programme aims to do this by giving school pupils a taste of what studying at Oxford is like.“It is wonderful that our partnership with East Lothian Council has already succeeded in encouraging talented young scholars from Scotland to apply to Oxford.“I hope Lewis and Thomas are the first of many who experience the programme and then set their sights on studying at Oxford.”

title: musselburgh-law-firm-shuts
story: The Edinburgh practice has acquired the clients of the Musselburgh legal firm, which has closed after more than  years operating in the town.Boyd Legal has promised a “smooth transition and continuation” of the service provided to Somerville  Russell’s clients who require legal services around wills and trusts, estates and executry advice.Estate agency and conveyancing will also be offered but court work and family law services will not continue.Somerville  Russell recently closed its Bridge Street premises, resulting in a number of redundancies.Diana Boyd, Boyd Legal managing director, said: “Sadly, the closure of Somerville  Russell illustrates the continued consolidation of the legal sector caused by the effects of the Covid- pandemic and economic uncertainty.”She added: “We have worked closely with Somerville  Russell to ensure there will be a stress-free and efficient transfer of the firm’s private client business and would assure those clients that they are guaranteed a professional service which will meet all of their requirements.“While there will be no longer a presence in Musselburgh, the important thing is that clients who are transferring over to Boyd Legal will notice no discernible dference in the quality of legal advice and professional and personal support that will be at their disposal.“We have Somerville  Russell clients’ deeds and wills in safe storage and will be writing to clients to reassure them about continuity of service.”Formed in , Boyd Legal is based on Queensferry Street, Edinburgh.

title: scotmid-prestonpans-move-refurb-complete
story: Scotmid Co-operative has acquired the former Day-Today site on Redburn Road, which was run by Ferhan Ashiq and his family for more than three decades before it closed its doors on Monday.The move comes as Scotmid prepares to undertake a major revamp of its existing store on the same road, to provide customers with an enhanced shopping experience through the introduction of new ranges and more choice.The plans also include the creation of a new job at the store.Scotmid will relocate to the former Day-Today site for about three months to continue to provide for its customers while the refurbishment is carried out.Mr Ashiq said of the sale: “It has been a pleasure to be a part of the community in Prestonpans for as long as we have and we would like to thank all of our customers for their loyalty and support over the years.“I am delighted that they will be able to enjoy the benefits of the new-look store that Scotmid is bringing to the area, ensuring the continuity of great service, choice and value for money that local convenience retailers deliver to local communities.”Work on the ,sq.ft store will see Scotmid build on its Food to Go offering, which will see new hot food ranges introduced.Harry Cairney, Scotmid president, said: “As a co-operative which aims to support and serve those communities we operate in, we’re very excited to be commencing our major refurbishment programme to bring a refreshed and enhanced shopping experience to our customers in Prestonpans.“We look forward to welcoming a new member of staff on board in a new role, which has been created as a result of this investment and I would personally like to thank Ferhan and his family for their many years of committed service – and wish them the very best for the future.”The new-look Scotmid Redburn store is due to open in May.

title: plans-new-youth-hub-dunbar
story: The proposals, expected to cost hundreds of thousands of pounds, could help drive forward the next generation of BMX and skating stars.A football pitch and play area were included in plans for  new homes at Hallhill North in Dunbar.Taylor Wimpey East Scotland and Hallhill Developments Limited were given permission for the new builds at the end of last year, with more than £, set aside for a full-size pitch and changing facilities.Councillor Norman Hampshire, council leader and ward member, revealed that that was just part of the proposals being brought forward, with the scheme tying in with nearby Hallhill Sports Centre.He said: “We are looking to create a new pump track and skate park along with changing rooms for the football pitch and a community cafe.“It would be a multi-generational facility however, in the evening it will be available for the young people to use.“They can come and watch television, potentially have a game of pool or other activities.”Funding is already in place for ious aspects of the ambitious project.However, there are still obstacles to be overcome.A planning application will be needed for the changing rooms, cafe, skate park and pump track.Youngsters will play a key role in the design of the skate park and pump track, with funding applications then being submitted to ious bodies.The planning application is expected to be submitted at the beginning of April, while work on the football pitch and play area could get under way within a matter of months.Mr Hampshire was hopeful,matters progressed smoothly, that work could start on the building this summer, and the skate park and pump track at the end of the year.The council leader felt that the proposed facilities would have a number of benefits to the community.He said: “People complain about young people hanging around and doing things they should not be doing and we want to give them something positive they can do.“My own vision is the cafe will be open from am to pm and we will be the operators of it but also I would like to have youth workers basing themselves within the cafe and going out into the community where young people are.”Mr Hampshire highlighted the plans during a virtual meeting with Dunbar Community Council.He said that a lot of work was still to be done, both on the site and in offices, in order to get the proposals off the ground.Mr Hampshire said: “It is a lot of work still to be done but we have made really, really good progress.“The woodland area is in pretty poor condition and there has never been any management taking place.“We have got some work to be done.“Drainage needs to be improved and some of the poor trees will probably have to be removed from there.“There was some damage done by the wind and that has got to cleared out.“Some of the ditches in there have been filled and never been kept clear – all that is management which needs to be done.“There is still wildle in the woodland and we will do everything we can to make sure we protect that.”

title: grange-road-closed-two-days-resurfacing

title: demand-new-houses-musselburgh-soars
story: The EH region, where Musselburgh is located, has experienced “a strong recovery” in the wake of Covid-, with sales exceeding £ million in March  – more than £m above pre-pandemic levels.Despite increasing popularity,  per cent of homes in the area sold for under £,, with apartments concentrated at under £, – more than £, less than the average flat in the Capital.The new report by Rettie  Co has revealed that areas such as Leith, previously considered suitable for buyers with lower budgets, are on the up, with EH postcodes still considered the most expensive in the country.It comes after the firm’s latest -home development, The Wireworks, under construction on Mall Avenue in partnership with independent property developer Dundas Estates, received about , enquiries in the last nine months.Dundas Estates, through a partnership with Tesco, East Lothian Council and NHS Lothian, acquired The Wireworks site after receiving planning permission to regenerate the former Brunton Wireworks site and neighbouring land in .The development will have bike store capacity for  bicycles, and electric car charging facilities throughout. Private gardens and balconies will also be available at some apartments.It was reported that “good progress” was being made on construction of the new Wireworks development, with steel frames and initial staircores now in place.The project is expected to be completed by  and the apartments will include  affordable homes.A showhome launch is scheduled for April or May , with prices expected to be released in May this year.Livingston-based Dundas Estates is committing, through Section  payments, to contribute up to £,, along with other partners, to local schooling and infrastructure.Calum Miller, director of new homes at Rettie  Co, said: “Musselburgh is becoming increasingly popular as it offers a viable alternative to Edinburgh within a reasonable price range.“Typical buyers that, two or three years ago, could have afforded a two-bedroom apartment in Leith, would now be struggling to purchase a one-bedroom for the same budget.“Musselburgh offers a lot more value for money, still within easy reach of the draw of the Capital.”The average house price in Edinburgh in December was £,, up . per cent on the previous year, according to the Office of National Statistics.In contrast, buyers in East Lothian are paying £, for the average home.Mr Miller said: “We’re currently seeing a spate of enquiries in the EH postcode and for good reason.“Being a commuter town just outside of Edinburgh, Musselburgh offers the best of both worlds – city convenience with an abundance of green space and amenities such as the River Esk, nearby beaches and Musselburgh Racecourse, as well as the renowned Luca’s ice cream parlour.”Craig Fairfoull, head of sales  marketing at Dundas Estates, added: “We are delighted to be working alongside Rettie  Co to help deliver reasonably priced, high-quality homes to meet demand in Musselburgh.”

title: east-lothian-schools-head-murrayfield-cup-glory
story: Loretto are in the under-s shield final of the Scottish Rugby Boys Schools Cup while North Berwick High School are desperate for silverware in the under-s shield final.Loretto will face Queen Victoria School from Dunblane, having progressed - against Preston Lodge High School in the semi-final in February.A school spokesperson said: "We are delighted to be competing in the under- Shield Final on Wednesday."Reaching the final is testament to the hard work and commitment of the players and staff, and we thank our wonderful supporters for cheering us on."We wish everyone taking part in the Scottish Rugby Boys School Cup Finals all the very best."The match will take place at DAM Health Stadium, the new home of Edinburgh Rugby, adjacent to BT Murrayfield at .pm.Before that, North Berwick High Schools under-s will also face Queen Victoria School in their final, having progressed to the glamour tie after their semi-final victors Loretto were disqualied from the competition for fielding an ineligible player.: North Berwick boys progress to national rugby final after Loretto disqualiedKen Muir, head of youth rugby at North Berwick, said: “Im delighted for the boys: theyll get their opportunity to play at Murrayfield in the final.”The match will also take place at DAM Health Stadium, kicking off at .pm.Entry is free for all matches and people are encouraged to come along and cheer on Scotland’s young stars.For more information visit here or go online at Scottish Rugby.

title: east-lothian-golf-courses-named-among-best-gb-ireland
story: Courses theand breadth of the country have been scored out of  by Today’s Golfer.The scoring is broken down into six criteria – design , setting , memorability , playability , consistencyand presentation .The Renaissance Club, which will host the Genesis Scottish Open for the fourth consecutive year in July, was rated th.The Tom Doak course is described as “a fine modern links” and scores a total of .Nearby Gullaneis ranked th and scores a total of .The publication notes: “Expect some fine views and consistency, as well as a beautully conditioned course – exactly how a links should be presented.”Ranked second in East Lothian and th on the list is North Berwick.The course is described as featuring “memorable hole after memorable hole” and “a must play” as it achieves a score of .However, top of the list for East Lothian – and fth overall – is Muirfield, which hosts the Women’s Open for the first time in August.Also scoring , Muirfield is described as “an awesome test in any weather, a trial of strategy, ball-striking and nous”.St Andrewstakes the top spot on the list.The list also includes a number of county golf clubs which are ranked from  to .Archerfieldis ranked , while Kilspindie is  and Gullane No  is .Nearby Luffness is ranked at  and, further along the coast, Dunbar comes in at  on the list.

title: martin-lewis-show-tonight--watch-cost-living-special
story: To help people navigate this dficult financial terrain, the final in the current series of The Martin Lewis Money Show will be an hour-long special that will go out live.The extended show is a cost of living special where money saving expert, Martin Lewis, will be offering advice on reducing the cost of bills and other tips to save cash.Always encouraging people to talk more openly about household finances, the end of the show will feature a live QA where Martin will be answering viewers questions directly.We’re gearing up for our finale on Tues th March and we’d LOVE to hear all about your wallet WINS from this series. 🤑Fancy joining our audience and sharing your success  Get in touch via the link: https:t.co bvfApEMq pic BxEyuiacThe Martin Lewis Money Show hour-long Cost of Living special will air tonight from  pm to  pm on ITV, featuring Martin Lewis himself along with co-presenter Angellica Bell.If you can’t watch live then you can catch up via ITV Hub.

title: russian-products-stopped-sold-uk-supermarkets
story: Many major supermarkets have already made signicant moves with Sainsburys renaming the chicken kiev to chicken Kyivs, the preferred spelling of the Ukrainian name. However, not all supermarkets have made such signicant moves as Sainsburys, with many choosing to remove the Russian staple drink of vodka. As well as others still shelving the Russian produces but no longer buying from the nation instead. Heres a full list of what each supermarket has stopped selling from Russia. We continue to be saddened by the news coming out of Ukraine. As part of our continued support for those affected, the Aldi group have committed to a further € million for established aid organisations ensuring help reaches those that need it most. #STANDWITHUKRAINE pic qUKCyThe brand has pledged to stop the selling of all products that are wholly from Russia. That includes two items they currently stock but have now been removed from shelves across the nation. Those products are the Russian Standard vodka and Karpayskiye black sunflower seed. Plus the brand also renamed the chicken Kive to chicken Kyiv. The budget-friendly supermarket most loved for their middle aisles has said they will stop selling all Russian source Vodka. Much of the stores products are not produced in Russia but they have committed over five million euros to Ukraine. Morrisons have also joined other supermarkets in their support for Ukraine with the stopping of selling Russian Standard vodka in stores. The sister brand to John Lewis is no longer selling Russian-produced products like vodka and a line of pizza over pellets.Elsewhere Tesco is no longer buying products from businesses that are wholly Russian-owned.

title: wordle-262-todays-wordle-word-8-march-hints-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you’re still trying to save your streak, then don’t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today’s word starts with the letter S and ends with the letter T.It contains two of the same letter.It is a word to describe a pleasant, not bitter taste. If you have given up on today’s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now. The Wordle for March  is SWEET. The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.On a statement on Twitter he wrote: “Since launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.“The game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .“It has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me – from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.“On the flip side, I’d be lyingI said this hasn’t been overwhelming.“After all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.“Given this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that I’ve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.”
