title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: slemish celebrations are back for st patrick s day
story: Slemish Mountain and the award-winning village of Broughshane will welcome thousands of visitors this St Patrick’s Day as the popular celebrationsto the area for the first time since .The traditional St Patrick’s Day climb of Slemish willon Thursday  March with a series of activities planned to make it a rewarding experience for all.Broughshane  District Community Association will provide the hub of the event in the village, with outdoor entertainment, including performances from the lively band, Ragaire, and the twenty-strong, Portglenone Comhaltas Group, traditional music and dance, street theatre, with crafts and face painting for the very young. It will be the first time since  that the traditional St Patrick’s Day celebrations will take place at Slemish following the outbreak of Covid-, with virtual events staged over the past two years.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, said: “St Patrick’s Day at Slemish and Broughshane is one of the most popular and best attended public events within the Mid and East Antrim Borough Council area with thousands attending it each year.“An exciting programme of history and culture has been put together for this event and I look forward to welcoming visitors to the area.”Chairman of Broughshane  District Community Association, Lexie Scott said: “We are absolutely delighted to be joining in the annual celebrations for Saint Patricks Day. We look forward giving the many visitors, who will come to climb Slemish, a very warm welcome to the village and the many retail opportunities it can offer.”The award-winning Naturally North Coast and Glens Artisan Market will attend for the first time, with over  stalls, offering visitors the unique market experience showcasing a wide range of artisan produce and high quality hand crafted goods. The one and a half kilometre walk at Slemish takes approximately one hour up and down and it is strongly advised that suitable clothing and strong footwear is worn. Sections of the short climb can be steep and slippery and might not be suitable for all. Don’t forget to pick up your climber’s certicate and medal back down in the village, though supplies are limited. There will be no parking at Slemish, Carnstroan Road or Carnstroan Lane, so a free park and ride service will operate from the former Michelin plant, Broughshane, just off the M.The shuttle bus to Slemish Mountain will run continually from am – :pm stopping in Broughshane village, so nobody will miss out on the free entertainment and shopping offers.This event has been supported by The Executive Office through Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s Good Relations Programme.For further information and download a guide for the day visit www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk stpatricksday

title: have your say on council s performance improvement plan 2022 2023
story: MID and East Antrim Borough Council has launched a consultation on its Performance Improvement Planfor the   period – its annual plan to support continuous improvement in the delivery of council services.During the consultation period, which extends to  May , residents, businesses and community groups across the Borough are invited to review the draft plan and have their say on Council’s proposed improvement objectives.Covering six key areas, the proposed improvement objectives for   are: Growing the economy and creating jobs. Supporting the communities within the historic conservation area of Carrickfergus, contributing to the sustainability of the local economy. Supporting MEA’s citizens’ health and wellbeing by providing quality, inclusive play and recreation facilities, and promoting safe and responsible outdoor recreation. Improving infrastructure to encourage electric vehicle uptake in the Borough to reduce emissions and protect the environment for future generations. Creating an Autism Friendly Mid and East Antrim Borough Council. Improving customer engagement and service delivery by enhancing Council’s use of information technology.Mayor of Mid and East Antrim, Councillor William McCaughey, is urging residents, businesses and community groups to engage in the consultation and ensure their views are heard.“As a Council, our duty is matched by our strong desire to drive performance and continuous improvement in the service we provide to the people of Mid and East Antrim,” he said. “To do so, we rely very much on their feedback and, as such, welcome all comments and suggestions received through this consultation process.“Underpinned by our Performance Management Framework, our proposed improvement objectives for the   period align closely to Council’s key priorities within our Community and Corporate Plans.“Our improvements focus on the issues that are important to the people of Mid and East Antrim, helping to improve the quality of le for all. For the upcoming year, we will also continue to focus on recovery and adapting to the ‘new normal’, taking proactive measures to minimise any lasting negative implications from the Covid- pandemic.”For more information about the Performance Improvement Plan and to complete the consultation questionnaire online, visit: www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk performance-consultationA printable copy of the consultation publication can be downloaded from the Council’s website and can be requested in an alternative format, such as large print or another language, by emailing communications@midandeastantrim.gov.ukHard copy consultation questionnaires should be ed to: Corporate Performance Team, Mid and East Antrim Borough Council, - Bridge Street, Ballymena, BT EJ.The consultation survey closes at noon on  May .The final plan will be taken to Full Council for approval before being published by  June , as is the statutory requirement.

title: new council ceo apparently bows out after only a few days on job
story: It is understood that the man brought to head Mid and East Antrim Council has left his post after just over a fortnight.It was said that Mark Parkinson was on sick leave last week but it emerged on Tuesday afternoon that he has apparently left his job for good. When Mr. Parkinson took over as Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s temporary chief executive there was widespread criciticism from local ratepayers.REVELATIONS that he was being employed at a cost of pound, per day sent shockwaves through the local community.Mid and East Antrim Council have been asked for comment.

title: ask the expert how can energy be saved in your home
story: Dr Ian Humphreys FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr Ian HumphreysMark BainTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThis week, Dr Ian Humphreys, chief executive of environmental charity Keep Northern Ireland Beautul, will answer important questions on green issues, and how we can play our part.Q. What is the best way to save energy in our homes A. If your home isn’t yet insulated, then the best way to save money is to get your loft and your cavity walls insulated. You will soon recover the money spent and there may even be a grant available to help.After that, turning your thermostat down even by  degree Celsius can help save money — andyou need to, put on another layer of clothes to keep warm.Q. Does only filling a kettle with as much water to boil as you need really help A. Every small action helps and that includes only boiling the water you need in a kettle. Heating more water than you need means you are spending money unnecessarily.And it is also financially beneficial to heat water in a kettle and then add it to a pot, for exampleyou are boiling your potatoes, as a kettle is more efficient at heating water than many stoves.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free title: behavioural change key to going green expert
story: Dr John BarryPeople have been urged to move away from a meat-based diet FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr John BarryAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWith heightened awareness around climate change and our environment, more and more people are looking for ways to “go green”.However, with the best intentions in the world, there are many perceived eco-friendly actions we are taking that turn out to be at best ineffective, and at worst counterproductive.Dr John Barry, Professor of Green Political Economy at Queen’s University, says there is a “general phenomena” of people undertaking green practices, but in another part of their le they are doing the opposite, counteracting all the “green good” they have done.“For example, people might recycle more or become more plant-based in their diet, but all the ecological advances of that will be cancelled outyou’re flying around the world,” he said.“It seems like common sense, but it is a recognised social behaviour.“There are also questions to asked around electric cars.“People think electric cars are the answer, but actually,you pop the hood on the electric car supply chain, you’ll find a lot of murky human rights abuses, and the extraction and exploitation of the environment in places where we have to mine things like zinc and magnesium, metals we need to make the batteries for electric cars.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “Really, the solution is, as we’ve seen from the pandemic, work from homeyou can, or use active travel — walking or cycling. Then you can use public transport.“I do have a concern around the promotion of electric vehicles in that it is sending out the wrong signal. We should be urging people not to travelthey don’t have to, walk or cycle when they can, then use public transport, and finally go down the electric car route.”Many companies and products promote themselves as green or eco-friendly, but when you read the small print, they really aren’t, says Dr Barry.He also says there are problems with a plant-based diet.Moving away from meat and dairy can help the environment, but there is a danger of becoming reliant on processed vegan-friendly foods and ‘fake meat’ products.“Not only could they be harmful, but ecologically, the production of these processed products is not environmentally-friendly,” he added.“By going plant-based in our diets, we need to go for fresh forms of protein and carbohydrates, not processed food.“Unlike eating raw vegetables, processed vegan foods or fake meats use more energy in their production, like oil and gas.“It’s much more ecologically-friendly from an energy and climate point of view to avoid processed food.“We need to be focusing on ‘farm to fork’ in the real sense of the term, as every part of the journey of processed food from production to your table uses up carbon energy — processing in the factory, driving to supermarket, refrigeration, cooking.“The are other forms of dietary choice you can make that use less carbon energy in the chain from production to consumption.”Related title: eco friendly alternatives seven everyday household items you can easily replace
story: Smiles better: durable and reusable bamboo toothbrushesGetty Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSmiles better: durable and reusable bamboo toothbrushesClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailFrom plastic free toothbrushes to reusable makeup remover pads, there’s an easier way to make eco-friendly choices in your home.And now that the focus is on going green and becoming a more conscious shopper, many local consumers are trying to decide what to swap, change and consider when it comes to being more eco-friendly.Making the sht to a more sustainable household isn’t as much of a daunting task as it seems, according to UK-based online retailer OnBuy which has provided the Belfastwith some examples of simple and effective everyday swaps for your home. rolls of Plastic free Eco Three ply toilet roll: £. It’s easy to get into the habit of purchasing a four or six pack of toilet roll every few days, but have you ever thought about the plastic you would be able to cut back on through bulk buying  With each roll costing just .p and boasting a three ply sustainably sourced tissue, this is a super simple swap.Reusable Make Up Pads |  Bamboo Pads with Laundry  Bag: £. This set is the perfect way to keep your skin clean and fresh without having to go through environmentally unfriendly wipes and pads. Simply dampen the pads with water, apply your favourite natural makeup removal product and gently rub onto the skin. Once finished, rinse the makeup pads and pop them back into their % cotton bag for safe keeping.Four Pack Bamboo Toothbrushes: £. Stronger and harder than wood, and more durable than plastic, bamboo is quickly becoming the go to material for sustainable swaps. With % plastic free packaging and a soft bristle, these great priced toothbrushes are an easy way of starting your sustainable swapping — you can also get them online with free delivery.Vinsani Bamboo Kitchen Towels: £. Another staple for any household is kitchen roll, so cutting down your plastic usage here is a good way of helping the planet go green. Bamboo grows - times faster than normal trees, making these bamboo kitchen rolls a great eco-friendly alternative. With two ply sheets, you’ll also be able to take advantage of a super absorbent roll meaning less waste.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up  pack Bamboo Cotton Buds: £. Well priced, vegan, and organic...making this an excellent swap. Cotton buds are so convenient, it’s easy to forget about their harmful impact to our planet and seas. Unlike your standard cotton buds, these super soft bamboo buds are biodegradable and eco-friendly, protecting our world from damaging plastics. An easy swap for those becoming more conscious about their choices without any forfeit.Typhoon Pure Active Bamboo Fibre Lunch Box: £. Getting a bit too used to taking a plastic bag or endless tupperware to the office  This Typhoon Bamboo Fibre Lunch Box is ideal for everyday use, cutting down your plastic usage whilst also promoting sustainability. The environmentally sourced materials allow you to reduce single plastic use whilst maintaining your style.Tala Cheese Food Wax Wraps Set of : £. Ideal for replacing traditional plastic sandwich bags and cling film, to provide a truly natural substitute to single-use plastic. Lasting up to a year with proper care and regular use, keep food fresh while making sustainable changes. title: how green is your candidate why its so vital to quiz politicians when they ask for your vote
story: Green Party NI leader Clare Bailey pictured. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGreen Party NI leader Clare Bailey pictured.March   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPoliticians are increasing recognising that immediate and decisive action on the climate crisis will not only influence votes — it will win votes.Indeed, for many Northern Irish voters, climate action will be one of the defining issues in the upcoming MLA elections in May.With these elections fast approaching, many candidates have already started leafleting and door-knocking. However, when a candidate knocks at your door, what questions should you ask them  More importantly, how do you know whether they are genuinely serious about what they propose To gain a deeper sense of the candidate’s knowledge and understanding of climate breakdown, begin the conversation in the context of the broader political landscape.There are currently two climate bills passing through the Northern Irish Assembly. These are subject to ongoing debates, reviews and amendments. Both bills have a target of net zero emissions. Yet while the Private Members’ Billaims for Northern Ireland to be net zero by , the Executive Billaims for .Read MoreClimate: ‘Supporting that Bill would have led to the loss of , jobs in the farming sector’ – Agriculture Minister Edwin PootsYou could therefore start by asking the following question: which bill do they support Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Given how both bills aim for Northern Ireland to be net zero, despite ying target dates, a good follow-up question would be to ask how their party hopes to achieve this. How will they get us there  What is their political strategy  What concrete steps will they take to help Northern Ireland reach net zero Northern Ireland is not only the last nation in western Europe to implement climate legislation, but we also rank th worst in the world for bioersity loss. Nature recovery is therefore integral to an ambitious climate strategy.It is therefore crucial to ask the candidate about how they plan to halt and reverse nature and bioersity loss. How will they promote regenerative agricultural practices  How will they create more spaces for nature  How will they prevent the decline — and potential extinction — of our valuable species and wildle There are also three sectors in Northern Ireland which could be uniquely affected by the climate crisis: agriculture, energy and transport. These three sectors are vastly dferent. However, what unies questions regarding the future of these sectors is the principle of ‘just transition’.‘Just transition’ is the idea that we should not moveto a low-carbon, environmentally-friendly economyit means sacricing justice or ‘fairness’. A just transition recognises that, whether it be people on low incomes or workers in the fossil fuel industry, no one should be left behind in the creation of a ‘greener’ society.To take energy as an example, fossil fuels like oil and gas remain the primary source of heat and power in Northern Ireland. We already know that fossil fuels are harmful to the environment, and they will not help us to reach climate targets. Beyond asking candidate about renewable energy systems, we must therefore go one step further.We need to ask candidates about how they will compensate for workers in polluting industries, who may find themselves without a job in a more sustainable world. What incentive schemes will they promote  How will they re-train or upskill iniduals  How will government invest in this The same is true for agricultural and transport sectors. Will there be grants or public goods for farmers who dedicate areas of land to rewilding or regenerative practices  Will there be further investment in public transport infrastructure, particularly in rural communities  How will government incentivise citizens to support ‘greener’ lestyle choices that are typically more expensive, like buying an electric car or fitting solar  at home Lastly, ask the candidate seeking your vote about what is important to you.Whether it be plastic pollution or food waste, this is an invaluable opportunity for you to ask the candidate about a specic topic that you care deeply about. This could be an ongoing problem in your local area, or a global issue which causes you concern.Raising more personal questions with candidates may subsequently elicit a more direct response from them.Elections are a rare opportunity for citizens to shape environmental policy, and focus political attention on the most defining issue of our generation: the climate crisis.Climate change will be related to every social issue on each political party’s manesto – from gender equality to healthcare.Voting for candidates who support ambitious environmental policy solutions is therefore arguably the most important action that citizens can take.Remember this when candidates come calling.Related topicsEdwin PootsClare BaileyClimate ChangeClimate BillMore On Edwin PootsFriends of the Earth: ‘Stormont’s one of the main reasons we’re so close to becoming the dirty corner of Europe’Greens call for independent environmental agency in NI after Poots announces English office to extend its Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:War in UkraineEnvironment In FocusHow Much Is Your House WorthSix NationsWeekendCoronavirusNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Kerbside boxes for every home to sort recycling ‘could save £m a year’ – and clean up the current dirty systemSystem used by many councils dirty, inefficient, and much more expensive than it needs to beSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIn the thundering heart of the facility where half of Northern Ireland’s waste is sorted for recycling, the scale of the operation is arresting.There are immediate observations — the banging, rattling, pounding intensity from vast industrial sorting machines, and the dirt which clings to surfaces. But more compelling is the awareness of how, just a few years ago, all of this valuable material was just dumped into holes in the ground.It’s a filthy business, but far less filthy than the alternative of landfilling the contents of our bins.Anyone who has lived near a municipal dump knows the stench, flies and rats which follow. The toxic nature of much waste means the sites are contaminated for generations, threatening groundwater and wildle.And yet,we all dump our waste into black bins, these sites must go somewhere. It is hypocritical for someone who refuses to recycle to object to a landfill site simply because it is close to their home, rather than close to someone ’s.As recently as , every year we sent , tonnes of municipal waste to landfill by last year that had fallen by %, even though the population increased in that period.Not all the reduction is because of recycling. Just over a decade ago no household waste was incinerated, but now , tonnes are sent abroad each year to be burned to make electricity.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up But recycling is the key explanation for the transformation. Driven both by legislative compulsion and growing public awareness of how we are polluting our world and wasting its resources, many people now put more into their recycling bin than into the black bin.Compostable and food waste is now collected separately and used for everything from garden compost to creating gas which can power lorries or make electricity.But what happens when the recyclable material leaves our homes  It is particularly hard to understand how the recyclable items put into blue bins or other comingled recycling bins — where all manner of materials are mixed — can be accurately sorted for processing.In an industrial estate in Mallusk, Bryson Recycling is where that process unfolds for much of the east of Northern Ireland. Bin lorries from five council areas — Belfast Antrim and Newtownabbey Ards and North Down Lisburn and Castlereagh, and Mid and East Antrim — arrive and leave in a constant stream.Mechanical rams push out each bin lorry’s contents into a hangar. A huge quarry shovel loads it onto a conveyor belt. Plastic bottles explode like fireworks as the vehicle’s heavy wheels drive over the material.The belt carries the waste into the deafening materials recycling facility . The process which follows is surprisingly labour-intensive, as well as using technology to separate the waste.First, a group of workers stand on a raised  and manually lt obvious contaminants from the conveyor belt.Secondly, the belt moves through screens designed to remove paper, which goes to a separate line.The third process involves a magnet that attracts steel cans, such as baked beans tins.That process is then reversed at the fourth stage as the remaining material is subjected to an eddy current that repels aluminium into a chute.The line splits into four conveyors which run through a sorting cabin — the fth stage — where a team of workers pick out materials by hand, aided by a prototype robot that recognises materials and lts then.The sixth stage sees plastics removed using optical sensors which recognise material based on how it reacts to light. A final process involves a worker again manually picking out recyclable items which have been missed.By this stage, more than % of the initial material has been removed. But it’s not perfect. I saw plastic bottles and paper dropping off the end after the final check.The conveyors move quickly and not even all the obviously recyclable material can be caught there is no time to explore items which look unclear. Small items such as bottle tops are particularly unlikely to be correctly identied, falling off the end of the line to be taken for incineration.There are two forms of contamination: material which is wrongly bundled together through the MRF-sorting process [such as plastic in bales of paper], and material which cannot be recycled at all at that facility and so is taken for burning.The contamination at the start of the process stems from a mixture of ignorance of ambiguous rules for what can be recycled in dferent council areas, and deliberate flouting of rules.Claire McCallum has been in the recycling business for two decades at Bryson. “We’ve probably seen nearly everything coming through the doors here,” she tells the Belfast .“We have an ongoing issue with nappies coming through, but also dead animals all sorts of things. We’ve had quite a lot of dead lambs.”Food waste in containers rots, both making the process of hand-sorting more unpleasant and contaminating the final material.What can the public do to help  “I think the best thing people can do is, rather than look at a certain type of material and think ‘oh, that can be recycled’, always check your local council website,” she says.“And the other thing is to ensure things are clean give them a quick rinse before recycling.”But the blue bin comingled recycling is only part of what happens at this facility. Bryson’s own-design vehicles move to another part of the site where no sorting is necessary because the materials have already been sorted manually as they were lted.It is this system Ms McCallum believes is the future.It produces far higher quality materials, almost % pure, rather than some plastic or metal inevitably ending up in a bale of paper. And it uses far less energy, unlike the vast electrical and mechanical demand of the MRF plant.There isn’t just an environmental benefit to the kerbside sorting. Counterintuitively, Bryson says it is also cheaper for ratepayers.“We have been looking at cost analysis and we have worked out thatevery household in Northern Ireland had wheelie boxes, it would save councils about £ million a year,” Ms McCallum says.The costs of sorting the material properly by hand are higher, but the processing costs signicantly less and produces materials which can be sold for a much higher price.So why were councils ever using blue bins  She suspects councils instinctively did so because they had been used to bins and bin lorries, and when told to recycle, they used what was familiar.When asked about this, a spokesman for Nilga, which represents councils here, said the issue was complex, but that the public should try to consume as little materials as possible and recycle the maximum quantity of what they do use.Bryson would like to see a single, consistent approach to recycling across Northern Ireland.Another benefit of improving the quality of recycled materials is that it makes it easier to sell to local firms and improves the quality of their products.Just % of MRF-sorted material stays on the island of Ireland for processing for kerbside-sorted material that figure is %.The high quality, low-contamination materials are not possible through an MRF facility, Ms McCallum says: “You can’t achieve that through recycling through a blue bin system.”Bryson’s plastic, paper and glass is recycled locally, supporting about  jobs and generating around £m a year.The paper is turned into moulded packaging like egg cartons and cup carriers by Huhtamäki in Dollingstown. Glass is melted in a Encirc’s furnace in Derrylin before being turned into bottles for Bailey’s, Bushmills, Fever-Tree, Bottlegreen and other leading drinks brands. Plastic is taken to Cherry Pipes in Dungannon where it is made into civil engineering and agricultural pipes.In one key area, Northern Ireland is now behind the Republic.Last year it became mandatory for recycling companies south of the border to accept ‘soft plastics’ such as the film lids to be recycled.Here that form of plastic makes up much of what still goes into landfill. It is not likely to be collected for recycling locally until .Dealing with waste is complex, but it can be over-complicated by government. For years, as the government prodded people to recycle and cut black bin collections, there was public grumbling.But public opinion has shted rapidly polling now finds public support for recycling.In the post-war decades it was a symbol of society’s growing wealth that a consumer could buy something new, use it for a while and then dump it in landfill because a newer model was available or a minor fault had developed. But that materialistic hedonism has become increasingly uncool.Now people want to recycle more, and do so more easily, but it is government that has not moved to satisfy this desire — either by not collecting basic items such as soft plastic or glass for recycling, or by using a system that will inevitably fail to recover a high percentage of what could be salvaged, and will inevitably contaminate even what is recycled.Stormont and our councils have the power to change this — but may only do sothey believe votes are at stake.Related topicsClimate ChangeMore On Climate title: time to fix the climate at any cost
story: Storm Eunice FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueStorm EuniceMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailClimate scientists are unambiguous about the need for rapid reductions in carbon emissions to meet the aim of limiting average levels of global warming to . degrees Celsius.While the climate challenge has been recognised for years, a lack of action up to now ramps up the urgency to act. It is now two years since the Northern Ireland Assembly declared a climate emergency. Similarly, Belfast City Council declared a climate emergency in October .Across Northern Ireland, the average annual land temperature in the decade - was .°C warmer than the period from the mid-s to mid-s. The st century has so far been warmer overall than any of the previous three centuries. Winter  was the third warmest winter for Northern Ireland since .The changes in climate that we are already experiencing are projected to continue and intensy. In the second half of the century, the amount of change that occurs will depend strongly on how successful we are in reducing greenhouse gas emissions globally.Annual temperatures in Northern Ireland are projected to rise by approximately .°C by the s from a - baseline average. Risks associated with rising temperatures, such as more extreme heatwave events causing impacts on people’s health, are likely to become more prevalent as a result of these projections, with their magnitude depending on the degree of change that is experienced.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the time of writing, Northern Ireland remains without a climate bill, although the expectation is that this will soon be resolved. The Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs , led by Environment Minister Edwin Poots, and Green Party NI leader Clare Bailey have bills that have reached the consideration stage in the Assembly.Whichever bill emerges, it is clear that signicant change to our socio-economic model needs to occur to reach any of the proposed targets. In , Northern Ireland’s greenhouse gas emissions were estimated to be . million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. Northern Ireland accounted for % of UK greenhouse gas emissions in , compared to approximately % of the UK population. Agriculture , transportand residential buildingswere the largest sectors in terms of emissions. Mindful of the need to address this and maintain a viable economy, Daera has produced a draft green growth strategy which is about creating more green jobs and protecting or re-purposing existing jobs where possible.An important part of the draft green growth strategy is the new energy strategy from the Department for the Economy. It notes an ambition to deliver energy savings of % from buildings and industry by  and meet at least % of electricity consumption from a erse mix of renewable sources by .While the legislation may be edging forward and strategies are emerging, the current Northern Ireland report within the latest UK Climate Change Risk Assessment makes for sobering reading. The Government is required by the Climate Change Act  to conduct such an assessment every five years to inform the UK National Adaptation Plans for England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales. The assessment covers  specic risks and opportunities in detail across themes such as infrastructure, health, the natural environment, international dimensions and business and industry.Taking the business and industry theme, issues such as increased flooding of business sites, increased levels of coastal flooding, access to finance, worker productivity and disruption to supply chains could all be at risk from climate change.For example, the annual bill for damage for non-residential properties in Northern Ireland is expected to increase by % by  due to flooding events. The expected annual damages for UK business properties from coastal flooding is expected to increase by % by .The Climate Change Risk Assessment also suggests that there is a risk that access to finance, investment, insurance, and capital for businesses are negatively impacted by climate change through decline in availability and affordability of insurance, a reduction in the value of assets and investment and increased credit risks and cost of capital.Across Northern Ireland, this is currently a medium risk, but it has the potential to rise to high magnitude in future.With these potential risks fast approaching, finding a path to net-zero is crucial. The net-zero carbon roadmap produced for Belfast is enlightening in this regard. Currently, % of Belfast’s emissions come from the domestic housing sector, with transport responsible for % of emissions, public and commercial buildings for % and industry %.Belfast’s roadmap includes an assessment of the potential contribution of approximately  energy-saving or low-carbon measures.I don’t think anyone knows where the money is coming from to pay for these initiatives, but it may be the case that a slowness to act has brought us to the point where we can’t quibble on the cost.Andrew Webb is chief economist at Grant ThorntonMost ReadDoctor faces tribunal over ‘cover-up’ title: as petrol prices soar heres how to make a tankful go even further
story: Consumer Council says that now could well be the ideal time to make the switch to an electric vehicleExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseWeigh your options: Don’t overfill your tankyou’re not planning a long journey FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueWeigh your options: Don’t overfill your tankyou’re not planning a long journeyAmy CochraneTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailWith fuel prices at an all-time high, drivers are worried about keeping up with the soaring cost of petrol and diesel.Combined with huge rises in domestic energy and home heating oil prices, the added pressure of keeping on top of travel costs can only heighten stress levels when trying to keep within household budgets.However, there are a few small changes that many can make to ensure journeys are as economically efficient as possible.Now might even be the time for motorists to consider the possibility of going electric — which can not only help the environment in the long term, but can help motorists cut the costs on travel.The war in Ukraine has had a massive impact on crude oil prices, and these are set to soar further as the crisis continues.Average fuel prices hit a record high last week in the wake of the Russian invasion on February , with even the cheapest petrol up p per litre in just seven days — and motorists could be paying a whopping £ a litre by next month.Increases of more than p per litre have been spotted in filling stations right across Northern Ireland in recent days.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up One year ago, the most expensive place for diesel here was charging .p per litre, while the dearest petrol was .p. Just yesterday, prices reached well above p for diesel and over p for petrol.Latest research from the Consumer Council shows that the Northern Ireland average unleaded petrol price is .p per litre, or £. for a -litre fill at the petrol station. Northern Ireland’s average diesel price is .p per litre or £. for a -litre fill.Petrol and diesel prices have increased by .% and .% in the last  months, respectively.Consumer Council Head of Transport Richard Williams has said that this increase is “driven by factors outside the control of consumers” and as with domestic energy costs too, this contributes to “a worrying time” for consumers.“It is likely that these price increases will encourage drivers to rethink how they make their journeys,” he said.“In the short term there are small things you can do to make the fuel you buy go further such a maintaining your vehicle properly and properly inflating the tyres. You can also use our free fuel checker tool for a weekly guide to the best price within your area. It is available on our website,” he added. In the longer term, Mr Williams has suggested that this ongoing economic crisis may force motorists to consider whether it is time stop using petrol or diesel altogether and purchase an electric vehicle instead.“This is something all car drivers are going to have to do eventually as the UK government has already announced a ban on the sale of all petrol and diesel vehicles by ,” he said.“Currently only .% of vehicles in Northern Ireland are electric but this is increasing, with a % increase on electric vehicle registrations from  to .“Many consumers will have questions around the cost of purchasing and running an electric vehicle, where and how they will charge it and even whether the battery range is sufficient for their driving needs,” he added.“The Consumer Council continues to work with government, elected representatives, consumer bodies and industry to safeguard the people of Northern Ireland and ensure they have the information and support required in order to make the move away from petrol or diesel.”While fuel consumption has a lot to do with the car you buy, whatever you drive there are things you can do to save fuel, save money and cut pollutiongoing electric is not an option right now. top tips on saving fuel. Keep your tyres inflated. Under-inflated tyres will make your car use more fuel so always check the pressure regularly.. Reduce the drag. This could be by removing roof racks or boxes which all add to your fuel consumption. Pack carefully to reduce drag.. Declutter your car. Less weight means less fuel soyou don’t need it right away, take it out.. Don’t fill your car up with fuel. Fuel is heavy so don’t overfill your tankyou’re not planning a long journey.. Brake and accelerate less — both of these burn fuel. Try to drive smoothly, accelerate gently and read the road ahead to avoid unnecessary braking. Decelerate smoothly as well by releasing the accelerator in time, leaving the car in gear.. Avoid stopping and starting where possible. Roll up slowly for traffic lights or coming to a stop at a queue where you might not have to stop completely.. Get your car serviced regularly. For best efficiency to ensure your car is running as smoothly as possible.. Use the right specication of engine oilto improve efficiency.. Don’t hang around — idling wastes fuel and your engine warms up more quickly when you’re moving so don’t start the engine until you’re ready to go.. Plan your journey — getting lost wastes fuel. Check traffic news before you go too as well as sticking to the sat nav.. Combine short trips — cold starts use more fuel so it pays to combine tripsyou can.. Walk or cycle —you’re only going a couple of miles or so, do you really need to use the car . Use your air conditioning wisely — at low speeds, it increases fuel consumption but at higher speeds the effect is less noticeable. Try opening the windows around town and save the air-con for the motorway. Running it at least once a week helps keep it in good condition.. Cut down on the electrics — turn off your rear window heater, demister fan and headlights when you don’t need them. Stick to the limit — going faster uses more fuel. Drive at mph and you’ll use up to % more than at mph and up to % more than at mph. Taking it up to mph can use up to % more fuel than at mph.Most ReadDoctor faces tribunal over ‘cover-up’ of child’s deathFloundering council’s £,-a-day boss quits just days into role – putting fourth title: mural of cregagh hero best back home where it belongs
story: Five years on, new image looms large over green where it all began for footballer GeorgeAmy CochraneTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA mural of football legend George Best has been reinstated on the Cregagh estate he called home — overlooking the green where it all began for the Belfast Boy.Back in the s — long before the roaring crowds and legendary goals — a young George Best could be found kicking a ball just a short distance from his east Belfast house on that very grass, Cregagh Green.It is now lovingly called ‘the Georgie Best’ by the children who live there today, and residents have said that they are pleased to see the mural back overlooking it.In , it was announced that the open space would be legally protected “in perpetuity” after a legal deed of dedication between Belfast City Council and Fields in Trust, to keep his memory alive. A mural of the footballer, who died aged  in November , was previously painted on the side of a block of flats adjacent to the green but because the Housing Executive had to carry out work on the buildings, it had to be removed, much to the dismay of residents."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ee .ece AUTOCROP w JPGeorgebest w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ee .ece AUTOCROP w JPGeorgebest w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ee .ece AUTOCROP w JPGeorgebest w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland ee .ece AUTOCROP w JPGeorgebest w" data-sizes"auto"  "The new George Best mural in the Cregagh estate in east Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe new George Best mural in the Cregagh estate in east Belfast But now, with funding and help from the Housing Executive, the Cregagh Community Association organised a new mural in the same spot of a young George Best wearing his Northern Ireland kit which was created by Belfast artist Dee Craig.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Marlene Dodds is treasurer of the Cregagh Community Association and said that the residents of the estate, including George Best’s sister Grace, are happy to see the mural back after almost a five-year absence.“The mural was originally painted lower down on the flats because the bungalows weren’t there, so after the work it had to be moved further up the wall making it bigger than the previous one,” she said.“But this one is just amazing, I can’t get over it, it’s unbelievable!”Marlene explained that the design was chosen by residents after ballot boxes were placed in a number of local shops and churches asking the community to vote for their favourite design out of six options.“I think they made the right decision picking this one because it’s just great,” she said.“The other designs had some writing on it but I think this image just says it all.“George Best started out here so it’s only right to have him looking over the green, back where he belongs, as I say,” Marlene added.A community consultation took place in  to discuss with residents about plans to create a new mural, but due to the pandemic, Marlene said progress had slowed on the project.“This is the only mural of George in the estate and it means something that he overlooks the field,” said Ms Dodds.“I think it’s inspiring for all the kids who play on the green, they even call it ‘the Georgie Best’ when they say they are going there to play football. It’s just lovely to have that.”She said that football teams would often request to play matches on the green instead of the G all weather pitch in the community centre.“There is just that sentiment with it, it is very special to us and to the football community,” she said.“It’s a bit mucky in the bad weather but it’s buzzing at the weekends in the summer, it just comes alive.”Marlene said that, due to the pandemic, there wasn’t much action happening around the green over the last two years.“It was sad that it wasn’t being used because no one was allowed to play football, but at the end of last year and now this year the kids and adults areback playing and it’s great to see,” she said.“Coming into the spring now it’ll definitely start to pick up again.“We have been in lockdown for two years and without our mural for five, but now George is back where he belongs looking over us.”Last year the childhood home of the football legend was transformed with a retro refit to take visitors back in time to the moment he signed for Manchester United aged .The house on Burren Way, where George grew up and his father Dickie lived until his passing in , was taken over by the EastSide Partnership and transformed to show what it would have looked like when the young footballer was still living there.Most ReadDoctor faces tribunal over ‘cover-up’ of child’s deathFloundering council’s title: ni must quickly introduce a refugee integration strategy says report
story: Ukrainian refugees who have fled the conflict sit with British government officials fill out paperwork as they seek to enter the UK, at the ferry terminal in Calais, France PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUkrainian refugees who have fled the conflict sit with British government officials fill out paperwork as they seek to enter the UK, at the ferry terminal in Calais, France Adrian RutherfordTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA refugee integration strategy needs to be delivered at pace in Northern Ireland, a report warns today.It found minority ethnic and migrant communities here are too often overlooked by policy makers.Read MoreNI is ready to welcome refugees, says local charityPortadown man transports  vulnerable Ukrainians across Polish border in London black cab‘Stormont must put pressure on Home Office over refugees’The cross-party Northern Ireland Affairs Committee concluded that support for refugees was ‘patchy’, and often an afterthought amid the daily focus on local politics.MPs said challenges faced by resettled refugees need to be addressed given the imminent arrival of people from Afghanistan and Ukraine.Committee chair Simon Hoare said: “Northern Ireland politics and public le has been understandably dominated by Green Orange discourse.“However, Northern Ireland is increasingly becoming more than Green and Orange and people from a range of other communities feel overlooked in politics and policy making.“We urge NI civil society to encourage greater representation of minority ethnic people in their own organisations, so that politics can be done ‘with’ and not ‘to’ them.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseGeraldine McGahey FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGeraldine McGaheyDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the time of the  census, Northern Ireland was the least ethnically erse region of the UK. But the  census is expected to show an increase in the ethnic ersity of the population.The Executive has published two racial equality strategies — in  and  —  but the committee heard concerns about a lack of progress.Today’s report notes that minority ethnic communities “may be largely invisible to policy makers” due to the lack of ethnic monitoring and data on the population.Natalie Donnelly from Unison NI told the inquiry how such monitoring “is just not there”, adding that “we have the Catholic Protestant other split in the monitoring, and that is it”.Other witnesses said they are still relying on  census data. Geraldine McGahey, the Equality Commissioner, told the committee that “all policy development to date has been flawed” as a result.The report states the absence of accurate ethnic monitoring data “is lamentable”, leaving little insight on the scale of demand or whether equality initiatives are succeeding.Northern Ireland is the only part of the UK without a refugee integration strategy, although a draft strategy has been published by The Executive Office.The report cites the experience of ,-plus Syrians resettled here since . The committee heard that cultural concerns and scarce language services made it dficult for refugees, especially outside Belfast.It stresses the importance of learning the lessons from the Syrian refugee scheme.“With Afghan — and almost certainly Ukrainian — refugees due to arrive soon, Northern Ireland needs to implement a refugee integration strategy with appropriate service provision throughout the region, and do so at pace,” it adds.Most ReadDoctor faces tribunal over ‘cover-up’ of child’s deathFloundering council’s £,-a-day boss quits just days into role – putting fourth person in charge in three monthsThe cheapest quotes for heating oil in your Northern Ireland postcode area as prices expected to remain high for two yearsNorthern Ireland braced for strong winds as Met Eireann issue gale warning for islandPortadown man transports  vulnerable Ukrainians across Polish border in London black cabTop VideosPlayVideo: Ukrainian soldiers use Northern Ireland built NLAW on invading Russian tanksPlayVideo: CCTV shows the moment thieves rob Moneymore store of k of stockPlayVideo: Two children hospitalised as car overturns in west BelfastLatest Northern IrelandGlentoran - title: one off 200 energy support payment to be rolled out from friday deirdre
story: The price of oil and gas has skyrocketed in the last year. Photo credit: Jacob King PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe price of oil and gas has skyrocketed in the last year. Photo credit: Jacob King PA WireChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA £ payment aimed to help those on the lowest incomes with rising energy costs is expected to be paid to people from Friday, according to the Communities Minister.Deirdre Hargey said those eligible for the one-off energy payment will receive the money directly into their bank accounts.However, the Sinn Fein minister revealed initial plans to begin the rollout of support on Thursday were scrapped after the Department of Work and Pensions system experienced a “technical glitch”.Around , people across Northern Ireland in receipt of specic benefits are automatically eligible for the payment.In a tweet, Ms Hargey confirmed: “The much needed energy payment of £ will now begin to be paid directly to peoples accounts on Friday.“I’m disappointed that DWP experienced a technical glitch resulted in payments not going ahead on Thursday.“I have been assured this morning that the issue has been rectied.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The support comes amid widespread rising costs, with global supply chain issues, among other factors leading to the price of oil and gas skyrocketing in the last year, with electricity prices also rising.The much needed energy payment of £ will now begin to be paid directly to peoples accounts on FridayI’m disappointed that DWP experienced a technical glitch resulted in payments not going ahead on ThursdayI have been assured this morning that the issue has been rectied— Deirdre HargeyMarch , People are also feeling the rising costs at the petrol pump, with the average price of a litre of petrol at UK forecourts rising from .p on February  to .p on Monday, according to the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy .Average diesel prices rose from .p to .p over the same period.Read MoreCalls for VAT to be cut from energy bills in Northern Ireland to help with cost of living crisisEverything you need to know about the one-off £ energy paymentThe weekly increases of .p for petrol and .p for diesel are the largest in records dating back to June .Iniduals will be eligible for the one-off payment , during the week of December  to December , , they were in receipt of one or more of the following benefits: Pension Credit, Universal Credit, Income-related Employment and Support Allowance, Income-based Jobseekers Allowance, Income Support.Iniduals living in care homes from December  to December ,  inclusive are not eligible for this payment.Those in receipt of payment of contribution based Employment Support Allowance only or contribution based Jobseekers Allowance only are also not eligible.Ms Hargey has encouraged people to further contact her department’s Make the Call service, which is in place to connect people with the benefits, supports and services to which they are entitled.To #Make the Call# you can phone   , text ADVICE to , visit nidirect.gov.uk makethecall or email makethecall@dfcni.gov.uk.Related topicsDeirdre HargeyMore On
