title: ‘Totally unacceptable’ boundary proposals
story: OPPOSITION to a controversial proposal to move a number of electoral wards in Downpatrick from South Down to a new Strangford and Quoile constituency will be outlined to the Boundary Commission today.South Down SDLP MLA Colin McGrath will be stating the case for the status quo to be maintained when he addresses Commission officials in Belfast. He has previously labelled the proposals to move the four wards as ldquototally unacceptable.Mr McGrath contends there is no historical, cultural, economic or educational link between Downpatrick and Comber or Newtownards, areas currently in the Strangford constituency that would be in the proposed Strangford and Quoile constituency.He said other political parties have made their stance clear via their respective submissions to the Commission, but was left ldquoaghast with Sinn Feinrsquos response which indicated that it was content with a number of areas including Malone Heights, Roughal Park, the Strangford Road, Ardenlee and Saul Acres developments and all of Saul and Strangford being removed from South Down to form part of the suggested new constituency.ldquoThe net result would be residents on either side of the Saul Road voting in dferent constituencies and I cannot comprehend the rationale for this, said Mr McGrath.The MLA said when he makes his presentation today, he will make it clear to the Commission ldquoin no uncertain terms that the proposal to move the four Downpatrick wards and much of Crossgar, Annacloy and Teconnaught into the proposed Strangford and Quoile constituency is ldquounacceptable.He added: ldquoLet us retain our links with places like Castlewellan, Newcastle and the wider South Down area and do not use Downpatrick as a scapegoat for their attempts to address wider electoral issues in Belfast or other parts of the North..prettyPhoto

title: 150th anniversary of Downpatrick church
story: THE Roman Catholic Archbishop of Armagh is to speak in Downpatrick to mark the th anniversary of St Patrickrsquos Church in the town.Archbishop Eamon Martin will celebrate mass on March th as part of a special St Patrickrsquos Novena mdash nine days of prayer mdash in the church where generations of Catholics have worshipped since .Poor Clares Sr Martina Purdy and Sr Elaine Kelly mdash who pioneered St Patrickrsquos Camino walk in Downpatrick two years ago mdash will help launch the Novena at the invitation of parish priest Fr John Murray.On March , Sr Martina and Sr Elaine, a former BBC correspondent and a former barrister respectively, will share their faith story, entitled lsquoOur Friend Patrickrsquo.The Dean of Down, the Very Henry Hull is also to take part in an ecumenical celebration on March  while the Bishop of Down and Connor, the Most Rev Noel Treanor, will celebrate Sunday mass on March .Fr John Murray, PP, said the St Patrickrsquos celebration would remember all the thousands of people who have attended mass and celebrated the sacraments in the church in St Patrickrsquos Avenue since its foundation.ldquoIt is an occasion to give thanks for those countless lives of witness and faith and to look forward to the future with confidence and hope in Christ, he said.ldquoIn , Fr Patrick OrsquoKane and the parishioners of St Patrickrsquos could not have imagined the events of two world wars and the rise and fall of Communism, the Second Vatican Council and the many other huge milestones that have come to dominate the landscape that is the th century.ldquoThey could not have imagined that  years after the church was built that we are just emerging from a pandemic. We pray for peace in the world, especially the tragic war being waged by Russia in the Ukraine.ldquoWhatever is happening or has happened in our lives we all need the mercy and healing touch of God. All are welcome to join our Novena in person or online at our Downpatrick parish facebook page. Services are also being streamed on St Patrickrsquos Parish at Itech Media.A representative of Koinonia, the community of John the Baptist, will speak about Jesus as healer on March .The Novena will include a lsquoSlemish Dayrsquo of prayer and fasting on March  in imitation of Patrick. Mass will be celebrated that evening by Bishop Paul McAleenan.Sr Martina and Sr Elaine, who now live a contemplative le as Poor Clares in County Louth, said it was an honour toto St Patrickrsquos for this special occasion.Just like St Paul, we met unusual kindness from the Christians in Downpatrick when we came to live in the parish in , Sr Martina said.ldquoSt Patrickrsquos spirit is very much alive and active and his impact cannot be underestimated. The power of his message mdash that only in Christ Jesus are we truly free mdash is as relevant today as it was in  when St Patrickrsquos was built and AD when Irelandrsquos great apostle arrived on our shores. Patrick remains our friend in the Lord.ldquoDuring lockdown we as a community have experienced many challenges including isolation and this is a chance to reclaim the joy of community and strengthen our faith, the faith that our ancestors clung tightly to and which sustained them with hope and love.Sr Elaine added: ldquoThis is an amazing time to rebuild on the old foundations through St Patrickrsquos Novena. It is in unison with Godrsquos perfect timing, when Downpatrick and the world begins to open up after two years of lockdown.ldquoIt is a clear sign of St Patrickrsquos influence in our present time, working through the power of the Holy Spirit.The nave of St Patrickrsquos Church was built in  and since then the parish has flourished with a new extension built in .It features the largest shrine to St Patrick in Ireland, with mosaics telling the story of his le, augmented by stained glass windows featuring his le and the le of other Irish saints inspired by his Christian mission.The church spire was added in  and pilgrim walkers on St Patrickrsquos Way have been visiting the church to explore its rich history..prettyPhoto

title: American singing legend Judy Collins on local radio show
story: AMERICAN music legend Judy Collins will the special guest on the Chris Scott Show on FM Down Community Radio tonight at pm.The singer, songwriter and musician has enjoyed a career spanning seven decades mdash and still going strong.Judy talks to Chris about some aspects of her long career in the music business, her Irish roots and her new album which was released last week. This is her first ever album of original songs.Chris will be playing some of the tracks from the new album and some of Judyrsquos classic songs.Judy talks about meeting with Belfastrsquos McPeake family, President John F Kennedy, Ella Fitzgerald, Nelson Mandela and much more.Judy had three UK top  hits in the s - Amazing Grace, Send in the Clowns and Both Sides Now.Tune in to the show and enjoy a conversation with one of the worldrsquos greatest singer songwriters.Chris will also be playing music from local singer songwriter Kevin Young and Showaddywaddy.The show will be repeated on Sunday at pm. If you are outside the FM signal area you can tune in online at https:onlineradiobox uk downcommunity You can also go to the Google Play Store and App Store and download the SERC Community Radio app.You can contact the show by emailing chris.scottfm@outlook.For further information on Judy Collins and her new album, Spellbound, go to her Facebook site at: https:www.facebook judycollinsofficial.prettyPhoto

title: Anne new chair of Friends of Down County Museum
story: THE Friends of Down County Museum has a new chairperson.Anne Curran was elected at the recent annual general meeting which was held in Denvirrsquos Hotel, Downpatrick.A former teacher, living in Downpatrick, she is keenly interested in history, archaeology, genealogy and the origin of place names.Supporting her on the committee are Dr Patrick Moore, as treasurer, Brian Leathem, as assistant treasurer, Lesley Simpson, as secretary, Jenner Taggart, as vice-chairperson, Gerard Lennon, Anne Liggett and Noreen Napier.The Friends of Down County Museum were established in  and were planning a major gt to commemorate their th anniversary in the months before the pandemic brought a halt to their meetings.Despite this, a piece of applied art by Alison Lowry was commissioned and finally installed in the museum.The purpose of the Friends is to support and promote the museum. They help to develop the museum and its collection and act as its ambassadors within the community. Members organise relevant activities as well as supporting the museumrsquos own programme of events.These activities include lectures, tours, literary and musical events, for social, educational or fundraising purposes. The Friends make grants, from their own funds or by acting as a conduit for other grant-aiding bodies who are unable to give money directly to the Museum. Such grants are for curatorial or educational purposes.At the inaugural meeting of the Friends in  the curator, Dr Brian Turner, spoke briefly about the work of the museum and plans for the future.He emphasised that community support and participation was vital and was at the root of everything the museum stood for.The first committee was elected with Patrick Forde as chairman, Dr Maurice Hayes as vice-chairman, Conac Hanna as treasurer and Noel McCann as secretary. Other committee members included Professor Ronald Buchanan, Frank Maxwell and Wendy Osborne. Since then, many other local people have given their time and skills through the committee.The Friends come from all parts of our community and even further afield. The main source of income is through annual subions, with occasional gts. However, there is also some capital as a result of a direct grant from the Northern Ireland government in . This was given in recognition of the Friendsrsquo potential for improving community harmony through peaceful exploration of our common cultural heritage. It is estimated that they have given the museum about pound, towards a great iety of projects during the last  years.However, perhaps more important is the long-term commitment the Friends have shown to the museum. They give their time, goodwill, skills, knowledge, experience and advice, on a voluntary basis, to help the museum in many ways. With their close association to the Museum they have witnessed the reduction in staff and understood the impact of the proposed restructuring.Friends in the art world, such as Richard Croft, Betty McCord and Jim Manley, have supported the museum by generous donations of their own work. Some have used their contacts to acquire works with large discounts whilst others have been able to alert the Museum to items for sale in auctions.The Friends donated Mixed farm, Slievenaman, an oil painting by Tom Carr, to mark the th anniversary of the museum, in . In , they donated Mourne Hayfield, a watercolour by Chris Dearden, to mark the th anniversary of the museum.They also purchased Silent Valley, a watercolour by Jim Manley, in , Landscape, Tyrella, an oil painting by Daniel OrsquoNeill, in  and part funded Down Cathedral and Southwell School, tempura on board by Patric Stevenson, in .The pieces of glass made by Alison Lowry, and which can now be seen at the entrance to the Cell Block, was part funded to mark the th anniversary of Friends. The inidual pieces are representations of objects associated with the lives of prisoners held in this building. The Friends also supported a residency for Australian artist Christina Henri commemorating women prisoners transported from Down Gaol.Friends with musical connections have organised tin whistle classes. The Friends also paid for a local harpist to play in galleries on summer Sunday afternoons and for the choral society at a Christmas event.Keen gardeners have brought plants into the museum to sell and opened a private garden to visitors to raise money.Car boot sales were another popular method of fundraising and the museum courtyard provided a useful venue for several organised by the Friends.Technical, photographic and conservation projects have benefited over the years from the Friendsrsquo assistance. Equipment and materials included a laminator, scanner, digital camera and archival storage. A drone pilot course was funded.The loan of St Patrickrsquos Head shrine from another museum was only made possible by its prior conservation, which the Friends paid for. One of the most important projects was the initial cataloguing of the D J McNeill Collection, by means of a placement, largely supported by the Friends.Young people have been encouraged to enjoy learning about history by Friendsrsquo funding for prizes for school competitions, poster packs for schools, and programmes for The Young Archaeologistsrsquo Club. The Education Service was assisted by the purchase of a photocopier and replica pots for children to handle.Publications have always been an important part of the museumrsquos work, in disseminating information about the collection, for setting objects in their historic context and most importantly, their relationship to people. To this end, the Friends have match-funded the annual Down Survey, - and .They assisting with the publication of two townland maps, which were freely distributed to schools and community groups. Books included A man stepped out for death, Thomas Russell and County Down, a collaborative publication to mark thebicentenary of the United Irish Rising of  and Aspects of Audleystown by Brian Turner, a book designed to help iniduals and groups study their townlands. They initiated, researched, wrote and published a recipe book, Food for Friends, in ,with all profits going to the Friends.Many facets of the High Cross project were supported by the Friends, including filming the whole project and the making of the replica High Cross. Restoration of St Patrickrsquos Cross and the interpretation  were financially supported.Exhibitions have benefited from the Friendsrsquo support in recent years with a major contribution to the extension at the back of the site was signicant. This included paintings for the new Tea Room.Talks and lecture series have been organised both in in the museum and at other venues with all profits given to the Friends.And dozens more: from the purchase of trees and shrubs for the garden at the back of the site to the purchase of a Papal bull..prettyPhoto

title: Aontú selects human rights activist to run in Assembly election
story: AONTUacute is fielding a candidate in South Down in the May Assembly election.The party has confirmed that Rosemary McGlone will be its standard bearer when voters go to the polls in  weeksrsquo time to elect five MLAs to represent the constituency.Aontuacute says it views South Down as a key constituency and aims to challenge the Stormont ldquoestablishment parties and provide genuine opposition to the to the broken Stormont system.A nationalist and human rights activist, Ms McGlone is a secondary school teacher in Belfast and a mother of four young children.Her party says that like many nationalists, she felt no longer represented by Sinn Fein or the SDLP and that rather than let herself be disenfranchised with no one to vote for, she has taken a step forward so that people like her might have a voice in Stormont.Aontuacute says that like so many, Rosemary has been ldquofrustrated by Nationalist parties who have abandoned their communities and supported discriminatory policies.It says the final straw for the South Down candidate came when Sinn Feacutein and SDLP MLAs voted for abortion up until birth for children with disabilities. Aontuacute says Rosemary also opposes the de-prioritisation funding of hundreds of local schools that is contained in the Integrated Education Bill.Her party leader, Peader Toacuteibiacuten, said , people are on housing waiting lists, , on hospital waiting lists for longer than a year, a quarter of a million people are in poverty and Sinn Fein and SDLP MLAs have voted for abortion right up until the birth of the child.He declared: ldquoThat the DUP has torn down Stormont in the middle of these very real human crisis is wrong and it must not be allowed to happen again.ldquoAontuacute is the only political party calling for the reform of the democratic institutions to prevent any one party tearing them down again or any one party preventing an Executive being formed in the future.ldquoThese le and death issues are too important for Stormont to be crashed over and over again. We are also calling for the suspension of MLA salaries for the political parties who crash the democratic institutions or prevent Executives being formed.Mr Aontuacute described Ms McGlone as a le-long human rights activist and nationalist who stopped voting for the SDLP because ldquoit abandoned her and so many communities to pursue identity politics.He continued: ldquoRosemary will lead the fight to give a voice to the tens of thousands of people who currently have no representation in Co Down. Stormont is broken and she will help lead the fight by Aontuacute to make the democratic institutions work.ldquoRosemary will also stand strong for the human right to le for everyone. She fully supports the integrated education sector but will fight for equality and parity of esteem in the education system, especially for rural schools and will oppose the Integrated Education Bill. All students mdash Catholic, Protestant and Integrated mdash should be treated equally. A vote for Rosemary is a vote for compassion and a vote to fix the broken system..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch lose out to UCD side
story: BALLYNAHINCH blew their chance to draw UCD into the relegation dogfight with a poor first half display into the wind on Saturday.There had been high hopes of a victory with a sizeable UCD contingent involved in the Ireland U- squad and the release of Ulsterrsquos Tom Stewart and Comac Izuchukwu to bolster the pack.However, the late withdrawal of the vastly experienced John Donnan meant a reshuffle with Tom Martin stepping in at lock and debutant Kyle Gill up to the bench.Playing into a gale in the first half, Ballynahinch failed to keep possession of the ball for long enough to exert any control on proceedings and were soon behind to a couple of excellently struck Chris Cosgrave penalties.The home side were denied a certain try when Stewart broke up the blindside and offloaded to a flying Conor McAuley but his foot was judged to be in touch.This proved to be signicant moment in the match as UCD scored a close range try from centre Dave Ryan soon afterwards to lead by  points with half an hour gone.Disaster was to strike for the home side on the stroke of half time when Ballynahinch found themselves pinned back from what should have been a comfortable position in the UCD half.They gave away a scrum penalty to concede territory but excellent defence forced a UCD knock-on and regained possession.Instead of playing narrow channels and reaching half-time no further in arrears, they were turned over in the middle of the field, allowing UCD to play an excellent kick behind a scrambling defence which then had to concede a goal lineout into a mph wind.The kick went straight out, handing the students a five-metre attacking scrum, and several phases later winger Ross Deegan scored. The conversion took UCD into a -point half time lead.The second half was dominated by Ballynahinch with the wind at their back and a big crowd roaring them on.Their maul was proving to be a real weapon and Kyle McCall was again the beneficiary with a try after  minutes after a superb maul.Tommy Donnan then had what seemed a certain try disallowed after another excellent maul, but when flanker Olly Loughead barged over on the hour mark to close the gap to eight points the home faithful could sense a famous win.However, UCD scored with their only attack of the second half through scrum half Richie Fahy to give the students some breathing space.Despite laying siege to the line, all the home side had to show for the last quarter was a penalty try with two minutes remaining and the students held on for victory and virtually assured their Division A status for -.Ballynahinch look destined for a nail-biting two-legged play-off against UCC to decide who goes down, but will hope to play themselves into better form over the final few weeks of the season.All support welcome at Garryowen this weekend.Ballynahinch : Nacho Cladera Crespo, Tom Stewart, Kyle McCall, Cormac Izuchukwu, Tom Martin, Tommy Donnan, Olly Loughead, Bradley Luney, Conor McAuley, Greg Hutley, Aaron Cairns, Ryan Wilson, Rory Butler, Ronan Patterson, Conor Rankin, David Cooper, John Dickson, Kyle Gill, Gareth Gill, Ruari Meharg, Yasser Omar..prettyPhoto

title: Dougan goal cancels out Sam’s strike in derby
story: THE local derby between Drumaness Mills and Killyleagh YC ended in a stalemate in quite horrendous conditions on Saturday.The Mills, who are currently on the back of a strong run of form and had won well at the reverse fixture a few weeks ago, would have been confident when welcoming old rivals Killyleagh for their Premier Division clash.The match at Meadowvale began at a high pace with lots of commitment shown by both sides in an effort to secure an early foothold in the game.In the early exchanges Rory Mason, Adam Keaney and then James McGivern all had half chances which they would have expected to have done better with.Somewhat against the run of play and with  minutes on the clock, Killyleaghrsquos Sam Carson rled the ball high into the top right hand corner of the net from the edge of the box with the home goalkeeper, Marc Reid, rooted to the spot. A fine goal at any level.Killyleagh were noticeably revitalised and buoyant following their goal, however, clever work from Callum Dougan on halfway sent Adam Kearney through in search of an equaliser with  minutes on the clock but he blazed over with the goal at his mercy.Killyleaghrsquos Conor Hamilton was becoming more and more influential in the game and continued to probe and prompt throughout, although he will be rueing his miss when he seemed better placed to score to put his side further ahead.On  minutes Rory Mason broke at pace and found Dougan, who forced a smart save from Aaron Carberry in the Killyleagh goal. Kearney, following up, trickled the rebound towards goal before it was hacked to safety before crossing the line.The Mills continued to press and a surging run down the right from Ben Campbell resulted in a fine ball across the face of goal but without anyone reacting it went out for a throw on the far side.Killyleagh had a corner in the th minute and in an example of the conditions, the now swirling wind took the ball directly out of play and with that the referee blew his whistle and brought the half to a close.Half-time: Drumaness Mills FC  Killyleagh YC .Clearly unimpressed with his sides first half showing, Drumaness manager, Mark Kerr, made two changes at half-time. Off went Rory Mason and Adam Kearney to be replaced with Eoin Rooney and Keegan Domican.As the game settled after the restart on  minutes, Campbell blazed a half chance over when well-placed following a corner for the home side.The next attack did bring the equaliser the home outfit craved. The ball fell to the feet of Callum Dougan after a Mills attack down the right looked like coming to nothing and he despatched it to the back of the net with aplomb. The clock ticked by with  minutes gone and both sides were now level.On  minutes Daniel Bell replaced Conor Carew in the engine room for The Mills and as the game heated up and became quite frantic around the  minute mark, McGivern was booked for two strong challenges in quick succession.As the game entered the final few minutes, Marc Reid made a top level save with an acrobatic reflex to push the ball onto the roof of the net when it didnrsquot seem possible showing shades of Gordon Banks.The away team were now pushing hard for the winner they craved and were blown up for an offside call on  minutes with Naseem Ouldhamiat through on goal.As the dust settled and a level of calm was restored the referee blew for full-time.A local derby which was keenly contested throughout and a draw was probably a fair result on the balance of play..prettyPhoto

title: First half nightmare for Ballynahinch at home
story: BALLYNAHINCH lost out to Portrush on home soil in their latest Ulster Intermediate League encounter at the weekend.lsquoHinch began strongly and on the attack from the first whistle as Alex Millar was quickly able to play the ball out from the back and up to Matthew Martin.The Ballynahinch player played the ball up to Kyle Patterson on the left wing, who was able to slot the ball in off the back post to put his side on the scoresheet.Portrush were quickly on the counter attack down the right-hand side only to be stopped by Ashley Brown and lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell.Portrush were determined to level the game and were able to slip the ball from the baseline through a crowded circle before putting the ball in at the back post.Leslie Harrison played the ball out to Scott Leetch on the right, who was able to pass up to Craig Harkness and over to Michael Carney and Jason Campbell up front.They were able to create chance after chance, but were denied by the Portrush lsquokeeper and their defence.lsquoHinch came out in the second quarter looking to add to the scoreline. Adam Dodds and Scott Leetch on the right and side were able to play the ball forward putting the pressure on Portrush. They were able to play the ball to Matthew Martin in midfield, who bounced the ball to Alex Millar.Alex was able to throw an aerial ball up to Josh Higginson, who went on the attack down the left side and started to create chances for lsquoHinch in the second quarter.Portrush were quick on the counter attack every time and were able to convert their chances in the lsquoHinch circle taking their score to ndash.Soon after, Portrush were able to win and convert their short corner opportunity. The lsquoHinch back four played back and forth with midfielders Matthew Martin and Jason Campbell creating space for the ball to be played forward to Ross Connolly and Lewis Higginson, who were unable to break down a strong Portrush defence. Portrush were able to add a fourth goal to their total just before half-time.Unfortunately it didnrsquot take long for Portrush to find the back of the net for their fth of the day after the restart. This came courtesy of a quick attack down the left-hand side before a perfectly placed shot across goal.This didnrsquot stop lsquoHinch fighting for every ball and looking to keep possession. lsquoHinch were able to win several short corners but were unable to convert their chances, due to a strong Portrush defence.When Portrush were able to break in to the lsquoHinch circle they won short corners. However, they were unable to convert these corners after trying several dferent routines.In the final quarter, Ballynahinch team-mates Alex Millar, Ashley Brown and Leslie Harrison continued to push the ball up towards the midfield and forwards but they were unable to break the Portrush defence or the ball travelling too quickly for players to stop before ending up over the baseline.Matty Martin and Adam Dodds had a great tag team run up the pitch with Matty having a shot on goal. Unfortunately it was stopped by the Portrush defence.The lsquoHinch men continued to press and win the ball with every try right up until the final whistle..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  March 4%2C 1992
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash A pound, environmental improvement package for Downpatrick has been one of the schemes temporarily affected by the Government freeze on public expenditure, it has been revealed.Down councillors have been told that the commencement of the scheme has unfortunately been delayed due to the current Government moratorium.However, councillors have been assured that the scheme will commence in the new financial year, beginning next month.The environmental improvement scheme involves upgrading English Street and parts of Irish Street and Stream Street.The chairman of Down District Council, Mr Sean Quinn, said the forthcoming conference on the regeneration of Downpatrick will bring positive financial support to the entire regeneration concept.ldquoIt is a shot in the arm for those pessimists who have been cynical about the regeneration board and it will give a morale boost to those who resiliently and optimistically worked through the moratorium to anticipate the coming to fruition of major and minor works, said Mr Quinn.ldquoI am particularly pleased that the one area which has been socially deprived in the Down District for some time, Ballymote, will get a boost as a sign that there is a positive commitment towards making the district work inspire of all.NEWCASTLE ndash Residents living near Newcastlersquos Donard Park have launched a campaign of opposition to plans to site a go-kart track close to their homes.A petition has been drawn up and a series of letters are being written by the residents of Shan Slieve Drive in an effort to persuade the DoE to refuse planning permission for the project.The track, which is to be sited closed to the Donard Park soccer pitches, will cover an area of approximately  square metres in and around a wooded area. The part of the track closest to the residents will be some - metres away.But Shan Slieve Drive householders say that is too close. In their petition to planners they say that the nearest gardens to the track are just  metres away and  dwellings and two major residential homes for the elderly are within  metres of the site.ldquoThe noise generated by the use of the track is likely to be highly detrimental to residents over a wide area, they claim. ldquoSuch a track is likely to operate from Easter until the end of September at least at weekends and almost certainly daily from am until pm during July and August. Residents would not be able to enjoy their gardens or leave windows openthe track was operating.KILLYLEAGH ndash The Killyleagh community has been urged to help combat at mounting problem of teenage drinking in public and vandalism.The appeal comes from the local Town Committee and follows a special meeting last Wednesday night involving the RUC, councillors and a council official.The townrsquos police sergeant and the three local councillors for the area ndash Mr Sam Osborne, Miss Margaret Ritchie and Mr William Dick ndash attended the meeting to hear complaints from the Town Committee about an upsurge in incidents involving young people.Town Committee secretary, Mrs Joyce McClurg, said many elderly people are terried because of the incidents. She said items are even thrown at passing cars in the townrsquos main streets.The discussion centred on the possibility of including Killyleagh in any further council bye-laws to prohibit drinking in public.The councillors urged the committee to contact the council to make them aware of the need for the bye-laws.BISHOPSCOURT ndash The owners of the former Bishopscourt airfield have outlined their plans to turn it into an international standard motor-cycle race track.Owners David Beattie and John Grfin believe the track can become one of the best circuits in Britain in the next two to three years.They pledged the former RAF base will be transformed over the coming weeks into a circuit as good as any in Ireland.And they have promised to bring over some of the top names in world motor-cycle racing, with the eventual target a world championship grand prix race.The duo gave a detailed outline of their proposals at a special press conference held in Strangford on Thursday night. It was ostensibly geared towards announcing the first race meeting at Bishopscourt for  years on March  ndash but as a result of the local controversy which has surrounded the project, they took the opportunity to answer many of the criticisms.Mr Beattie said: ldquoWe believe racing at Bishopscourt will put this end of the county on the map.ARDGLASS ndash A claim has been made this week that Ardglass fishermen will not benefit from a trawler decommissioning scheme announced by the Government.Local SDLP councillor Mr Dermot Curran says Ardglass trawler men will be allowed ldquovery littleany of the pound million which has been earmarked for the scheme.The pound million is intended to over the entire UK fishing fleet over a two-year period. The money will be paid to owners wishing to leave the industry, therefore reducing fishing capacity.Mr Curran said the money on offer is too little to help local fishermen.ldquoThere are  boats in Ardglass. A number of owners want to leave the industry, but this will not let them get out, he added.Mr Curran said Northern Ireland fishermen were in dficulty, with some living on the breadline.Accusing the Government of selfishness, Mr Curran continued: ldquoThe level of funding for this scheme is disgraceful.He added: ldquoI will be asking our local MP, Mr Eddie McGrady, to come to Ardglass to make sure that the case of local fishermen is given a fair hearing.CROSSGAR ndash A high school headmaster has warned that teachersrsquo jobs are at risk unless the Government makes alterations to the LMS funding system.Mr Colm Hanna, principal of Crossgarrsquos St Colmcillersquos High School, said this week that unless the Government removes the responsibility of teachersrsquo salaries from school budgets then staff may be laid off.Addressing his schoolrsquos annual prize distribution on Wednesday night, Mr Hanna said it was wrong for schools to have to make the decision on how many teachers should be employed and their levels of pay.ldquoOn introduction the Government was at great pains to assure us that the purpose of LMS was to enable schools to decide their own priorities in the allocation of funds and thus enrich the educational experience offered to our pupils, said Mr Hanna.ldquoWhat was not said, of course, was that the Government had tired of the antics of the teaching unions and their demands for better promotion prospects and smaller classes, and it decided to off-load the problems, via LMS, on to inidual schools who now have to take the decision about class size, the number of teachers to be employed and their levels of pay, he added.SEAFORDE ndash A new phase in the drive to plant one million new trees in Northern Ireland was officially launched at a plantation near Seaforde yesterday.The campaign is organised by the Northern Ireland branch of Conservation Volunteers, who have created the symbolic Million Tree Wood on a -acre site owned by local farmer Mr Alan Chambers.The Seaforde plantation contains some , tress and over the next few years it will serve as the focal point for the Conservation Volunteersrsquo campaign to reforest Northern Ireland, which is the least wooded region of the European Community.The organisation aims to plant a million trees throughout the province and their campaigns was given a prestigious launch yesterday by representatives of the Department of Agriculture, the Department of the Environment, the Ulster Tree Committee, Conservation Volunteers, campaign sponsors Esso and pupils from two local schools..prettyPhoto

title: Keep Festival of Flight flying
story: AN appeal has been issued to Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ensure that next yearrsquos international Festival of Flight in Newcastle goes ahead.The move comes after it was revealed three weeks ago that the highly popular event, which was last held in , would not take place this summer.The decision to abort the festival was taken during a behind-closed-doors discussion during a meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.Council officials say that due to the challenges in planning such a major festival, securing commitments from participants and with the uncertainty caused to date by the pandemic, organising this yearrsquos event would not be possible.DUP councillors Glyn Hanna and Kathryn Owen said confirmation that the festival would not take place this summer was ldquodevastating for local businesses, thousands of people who regularly attend the event and aviation enthusiasts.They said they were ldquohugely disappointed that the event would not go ahead, given its massive popularity and the contribution it makes to the local economy.ldquoWe understand the timeframe between the Northern Ireland Executive lting the Covid restrictions and the proposed date for the air show was too narrow to arrange this event safely, the councillors said in a statement.ldquoThe DUP grouping plan to propose at the next full council meeting that the date for next yearrsquos Festival of Flight is firmed in the events diary, ensuring this event is safe for years to come.Last week it was confirmed that the councilrsquos decision to cancel the festival was taken without consulting one of its key partners.The Ulster Aviation Society mdash which has played a major role since the inaugural festival mdash has described its disappointment at the cancellation decision.Regularly attracting in the region of , people to the resort in the summer, the flagship tourist event has been a major success for over a decade.The Ulster Aviation Society said it was ldquodisappointed and dismayed about the cancellation of the air show and the fact that the organisation had not been consulted.Society chairman Ray Burrows said it was ldquoastonishing that the event had been ldquoshot down in secret, with no reasonable explanation.He said the Society would be pleased to meet with the council to discuss the matter and to help Newcastle demonstrate in a powerful, popular way, how important aviation future and heritage are to Northern Ireland.Mr Burrows suggested that unless the councilrsquos decision is reversed, or at least re-assessed, he expects there will be tremendous disappointment from the public.The international festival was cancelled in  because of bad weather and in  and last year because of the Covid- pandemic it was also grounded.A council spokeswoman, who did not respond in time to meet last weekrsquos production deadline, said proposals for the local authorityrsquos - tourism events programme have not yet been considered.She added: ldquoDetails of the confirmed events programme will be announced in due course, subject to ratication by full council..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland £1M Pitch Plans
story: LOUGHINISLAND GAC has unveiled details of an ambitious development plan that could cost in the region of pound million.The proposed investment paves the way for the provision of ultra-modern facilities including a new full-sized floodlit pitch in tandem with a floodlit walking trail, ball wall, play area, spectator stand, coffee shop and enhanced changing rooms.The club hopes to raise the finance needed to fund the investment with the proposed new pitch suitable for hosting championship games in the future. The development plan for a -acre site also features a new training area adjacent to the current Macartan Park site.Local people have had a chance to view the proposal during a recent public consultation, with the club appealing for anyone who has not yet had say on the future of Loughinisland GAC to do so by the March  deadline.Club chair, Louise Kearney, explained the first consultation was held two months ago when people were asked for their ideas on how to ldquorevitalise the clubrsquos facilities.ldquoWe think we have included everything the community has wanted us to incorporate and now we are at the finalising stage of plans, she continued.ldquoWe have listened to the community and want to produce something that is of benefit to everyone.ldquoThe club want these facilities to be available to both members and non-members, including taking advantage of the proposed floodlit walkway.Ms Kearney added: ldquoNow is the time to have your voice heard and make a dference in the future of the club.Club officials say the feedback received from neighbours, club members and the community will play a pivotal part in finalising proposals to be submitted for formal planning approval.Assessments in relation to traffic, flood risk and drainage, the potential impact of lighting and bioersity issues are being completed in relation to the finalised plans.A project team set up to oversee the exciting plans will use the feedback gathered from the consultation and the results of the assessments in drafting the design of the development project to proceed to the planning stage.The club says it is under no illusion of the effort required to raise the funds and aims to do so in ious ways.Grants and the clubrsquos weekly lotto are some of the avenues being explored to help boost the fundraising effort and the so-called ldquoBlue Wall project. An initial , bricks will be available.The initiative allows people to purchase bricks mdash priced pound each mdash to invest in the future of Loughinisland GAC and fast-track plans towards building a more modern environment at the club.Each purchased brick will be fitted with a stainless steel plaque placed on a frame which will be prominent on the gable wall of the clubhouse.The plaque can be inscribed with a name, family name or business and location to be displayed forever as a reminder of those who contributed to the success of the plans.When development work has been completed the wall will be moved to a secure site close to the new pitches.For more information on the pitch or to submit a feedback form email loughinislandgacnewpitch@gmail.Alternatively, feedback forms can also be filled out on the clubrsquos website by visiting http:www.loughinislandgac..prettyPhoto

title: Matthew gets his second highest score from judges
story: LOVE Island heart-throb Matthew MacNabb has got through to the final six of RTErsquoS Dancing With The Stars mdash and is dating a new girlfriend.The Downpatrick man impressed the judges on Sunday evening with his strong Paso Doble for its ldquogreat characterisation.The dance with professional dance partner Laura Nolan is inspired by the movements of a Spanish matador and bull.The  year-old gave a passionate performance in the dramatic dance to the song, Live and Let Die by Wings in the showrsquos Big Band week played by the RTE Orchestra.He told the Recorder: ldquoI loved this week. It was a strong, powerful and intense experience so Irsquom glad it came across well. I could do that performance every week. It was my second favourite performance after the contemporary ballroom.The score of  was also his second highest of the competition, after the moving dance that he dedicated to his late friend, Ryan Freeman, who died in an accident shortly before he went on to Love Island.Matthew believes that his performance is improving as he is starting to enjoy the dance process.ldquoI think itrsquos easier for me to focus now because Irsquom really enjoying it. There are only three more rounds to the final so Irsquom fully locked in. I really want to prove that I can become a really good dancer, he saidItrsquos a highly pressurised experience, now with the dance-off it makes it even more intense. Somehow itrsquos made it more enjoyable.ldquoI just got to pray that people keep up voting and supporting. I want to be the first Northerner to win it so Irsquoll do everything I can.Judge Brian Redmond said of his performance: "This Paso Doble summed up your journey on Dancing with the Stars so far. It was just full of contrast mdash the ridiculous and the sublime."He also complimented Matthewrsquos "really great characterisation" but said he was "a little bit robotic in the hands"."Compared to what weve seen you do so far, that was a very good Paso", he concluded.Loraine Barry told him: "Its all about getting into character, you then have to show us the Paso Doble steps which Im delighted to say you did. This is a big dance and I think its a big success for you tonight."Arthur Gournounlian added: "You look ine tonight! You committed to this dance emotionally and physically. Im so happy you came back from last weeks Cha Cha and brought us this.Apart from learning how to dance, Matthew also revealed to the Irish Mail on Sunday that he met a girl through the show.ldquoIrsquove been dating a few weeks now. Itrsquos early days, so I want to keep it relatively quiet. But she does live in Dublin.Matthew, who failed to couple up on Love Island, didnrsquot reveal the identity of the lucky lady, but added: ldquoShe is well known ndash we met through the show [Dancing With The Stars].Check out Matthewrsquos progress on Dancing With The Stars this Sunday at .pm on RTEacute One..prettyPhoto

title: McMenamin the hat trick hero for highflying Glens
story: DOWNPATRICKrsquoS Conor McMenamin netted a hat-trick as Glentoran ed to the top of the Danske Bank Premiership with a - away win at Glenavon on Saturday.McMenamin, picking up the match-ball at Mourneview Park, saw him move onto  league goals for the season so far, before going onto say his target is .ldquoThatrsquos  league goals for me this season, said the  year-old.ldquoI have been wanting to add goals to my game and thankfully Irsquove managed to do that.ldquoI always set out for double figures the next target is . But I donrsquot care who scores as long as we win, especially at this stage of the season.Matthew Snoddy scored with a sublime strike into the top corner to put the Lurgan Blues in front before McMenamin netted the first goal of his hat-trick with a composed eight-yard finish to level.Gary Hamiltonrsquos side then retook the lead when Peter Campbell made a mazy run before firing low into the bottom corner of the net beyond Aaron McCarey.Jay Donnelly headed in the equaliser after a superb weighted cross from Rory Donnelly, before McMenamin added his second after his effort that looked very much like a cross found its way beyond James Taylor.Deep into added time the hat-trick was sealed for the Downpatrick-native when he cracked in a powerful strike to confirm the east Belfast side where heading back to the summit.McMenamin went on to add: ldquoThis is probably the best season Irsquove had.He continued: ldquoIrsquom  years-old now, Irsquom not a kid anymore and Irsquom taking my game serious and Irsquom working hard.ldquoBeing full-time now has allowed me to improve my game and look after myself and be in the gym a bit more. All round, my numbers and the way Irsquom playing is showing on the pitch.He added: The boys are buzzing in there but itrsquos just three points. We move on and focus on the Irish Cup next week, and then we have a massive one against Cltonville the following week.The former Linfield , Warrenpoint Town and Cltonville man also hit his th Irish League goal when he equalised in Saturdayrsquos showdown in Lurgan.Lurgan Blues boss Hamilton was very humble and described McMenamin as the ldquobest player in the league.ldquoWe were the dominant team in the second half but their second and third goals were really poor while in Conor McMenamin they have the best player in the league at this time, said Hamilton.Crossgarrsquos Andy Waterworth came on as a substitute for Glenavon against one of his former sides.Meanwhile Ballynahinchrsquos Greg Hall played in Portadownrsquos crucial - victory over Warrenpoint Town at the bottom of the table.Hall, who has been an ever present for the Ports this season, saw his side move five points clear of their opponents in the battle against relegation..prettyPhoto

title: Moved to tears
story: A KILLYLEAGH couple have spoken of their fears for relatives caught up in war-torn Ukraine.Brian and Wendy Poxon say there have been endless tears in their house since the Russian invasion last week.Their son, Mark, is married to a Ukrainian woman, Olga, who has many family members back in her homeland.Some of them live in or close to Kyiv, the capital city, which has come under heavy and repeated rocket and artillery fire in recent days.Mr and Mrs Poxon say they have been left distraught by images of the conflict, with terried families huddled in shelters, basements or corridors and tens of thousands fleeing their homes.At least  civilians have been killed, with  more wounded, but the real figures are likely to be considerably higher.More than half a million people are believed to have left Ukraine in the biggest invasion of a European country since the Second World War.Yesterday there were reports of a huge Russian armoured convoy closing in on Kyiv.Mr Poxon said Mark and Olga, who live in England, have been in touch with Olgarsquos family.ldquoShe has been told that at the moment her relatives and friends are still alive mdash not safe, but still alive, Mr Poxon remarked.Mr Poxon said his daughter-in-law was extremely concerned at the situation in her homeland and that he shared her distress.ldquoWe have been watching the news and there has hardly been a dry eye in our house since the invasion began last Thursday.ldquoThe people are in an utterly dire situation. We should not be having a war in a modern European society.Mr Poxon said he met many of his daughter-in-lawrsquos relatives and friends whwen she married their son in  mdash the couple met while at university in Nottingham mdash and that Olga and her parents attended a Christmas Eve carol service in Down Cathedral last year.He also revealed that he and his we were members of the Belfast Philharmonic Choir which sang in the city of Lviv in western Ukraine some time ago.ldquoBoth at Markrsquos wedding and in Lviv we met many Ukrainians and today our heart goes out to them, he said.ldquoMany of those people who we met sang to or danced with may well be standing in fields, villages, towns or cities with weapons in their hands, hiding in shelters or fleeing for their lives to the borders of friendly states.ldquoIn Lviv we met Marta who was our guide to the city. She spoke passionately, but without malice, on the history of Ukraine and how over its history it had been occupied by Poland, Nazi Germany and Russia.ldquoDuring our tour she took us to a church where we saw strings of white paper doves ascending to heaven, each one representing a le lost in the conflict since , and a board of photographs of young men and women who had also given their lives for their country. I dare say that many more will be added in the days and weeks to come.Mr Poxon continued: ldquoMarta spoke passionately about her beloved Ukraine and like all Ukrainians longed to live in peace in a democratic country where they had the freedom to live, work, play and worship as they pleased. Where they could elect their government and decide where they wanted to go instead of being dictated to.ldquoThe ordinary Ukrainian does not point to the east and say there is the great Satan, nor do they look to the west as their great salvation. They merely want to live in the peace and democracy which we in the west enjoy.ldquoAs we all now know on Thursday, February , a day which will go down in the annals of infamy, those hopes and dreams were shattered into a million pieces by the invasion..prettyPhoto

title: Plans to revive Dunleath Park are welcomed
story: A TIMETABLE for an ambitious revitalisation plan for Dunleath Park in Downpatrick is to be drawn up, it has been confirmed this week.A dedicated skateboard park and cycle pump track will be the first projects to get off the ground in tandem with a new tree planting programme.The park borders Lower Market Street, Thomas Russell Park, Vianstown Road and the Ballydugan Road industrial estate with local politicians and Newry, Mourne and Down Council recognising its tremendous development potential.The development blueprint is being put together by the local authority which has already delivered a new .km walking track along at the sports pitches with Dunleath Park preparing to host its first ever parkrun in the near future.Last year, local politicians met with Rivers Agency officials to discuss the development of Dunleath which is home to a number of sports pitches and is used extensively by the Downpatrick Youth Football League and other sports clubs.Keen to see the expansive area developed to its full potential, councillors have also met with the districtrsquos planning officials to discuss with them proposed developments that would be acceptable.Itrsquos understood that in addition, soccer and GAA pitches are in line for an upgrade as part of the plan to transform Dunleath Park into a sporting and recreational hub.Politicians are united in the drive to develop such a hub at an area which has suffered from a signicant lack of local authority investment over decades.In addition, they say the potential flooding risk at the park must not be used to stle all suggested proposals moving forward. Land at the rear of Russell Park is not deemed a flooding risk.Late last year, politicians said they are keen to see a wide-ranging development plan for the town centre location and while they accept that it may not be possible to deliver everything that will be in the blueprint at the same time, they want to aim high and also target potential funders to finance what will be an ambitious project.Downpatrick area councillors met with senior council officials last week to discuss proposals for the development of the park with the focus on maximising the opportunities that Dunleath offers.It has been agreed that a paper detailing plans for the new skateboard park and pump track will be outlined at a forthcoming meeting of the local authorityrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee.A working group has been set up to oversee the future of the park and its members have taken a close look at the existing sports pitches, with many keen to provide at least one G or G pitch which would provide a facility that could be used all year round.Downpatrick councillor, Oonagh Hanlon, described the development plans for Dunleath as ldquoexciting and praised the local authorityrsquos sensible approach to maximise its potential.She also conceded that while parts of the park present challenges as they are included within a flood plain, there is agreement aiming local politicians on the way forward.ldquoWe need to press ahead with what is achievable in the short term at Dunleath Park, whilst keeping an eye on a longer-term strategy. I am pleased that Downpatrick area councillors can work collectively for progress in the area, she added.Itrsquos understood that details of Downpatrickrsquos first ever parkrun event are being finalised and that once the date of the K event has been confirmed, the event will become an annual event for runners of all abilities.Hugely popular across the globe, those working to bring the event to Downpatrick say it has the potential to provide the local economy with a boost, bringing in many competitors from outside the town.Downpatrick Town Committee is behind the ambitious plan for the new parkrun which it believes will bring the local community closer together and may encourage people who have never run before to get out and enjoy themselves in an event where there is no time limit and no one finishes last..prettyPhoto

title: Recovery is possible to restore bond with you and eating food
story: WITH the pandemic dictating to us over the last two years, there has been an increase for those struggling to manage their dficult feelings, sudden le changes, isolation and trying to gain a sense of control mdash which has resulted in an increase of cases for the treatment of eating disorders.Eating disorders, or a disordered pattern of eating, can arise when a person uses food to cope with painful situations or uncomfortable feelings.Problems with food develop when it is used for emotional rather than physical reasons, such as feelings of anxiety, anger or guilt. The food serves as a stress reliever and in many cases initially the person is not aware of what they are doing.In this day and age of dieting, health and fitness, it is sometimes dficult to ascertain the dference between someone who has an eating disorder and a person who is simply weight conscious.The main ingredient present in a person with an eating disorder is the use or abuse of food to cope with dficult feelings, whereas a weight conscious person may simply want to lose weight for a wedding, an occasion, to fit into an outfit.It is the psychological and emotional implications that separate the weight conscious person from the person with an eating disorder. Unfortunately, some embarking on a weight loss trail start out innocently to lose lsquoa few poundsrsquo, however over a period of time a personrsquos brain and body chemistry can be affected by the diet they have chosen and as a result the brain and bodybecome impaired.Possible causesThere is no single cause for eating disorders, as there are many factors pertaining to them. The common thread seems to be a supersensitive nature, low self esteem and an inability to respond appropriately to uncomfortable feelings.The good news is recovery is possible and a person can restore their relationship with themselves and with food. All iniduals have their own unique personal issues that contribute to their eating disorder, so treatment has to be tailored to the iniduals specic needs, personality and lestyle.Who develops disorders Anyone can develop an eating disorder, regardless of age, sex cultural background, etc, and it is not unusual for an eating disorder to surface in middle age. Research suggests that there may also be a genetic disposition to eating disorders and a link to certain personality types.However, there are certain factors pertaining to eating disorders and anyone can develop a disordered pattern of eating. A traumatic event, disordered perception, being abused, being bullied, a long term illness, a death, negative influences from a family member or a friend can all have a part to play in the symphony that can create issues around food.What are the categories There are several categories of eating disorders. However the main culprits are anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge eating disorder and other related disorders.These disorders centre around extreme or potentially dangerous eating and weight control behaviours which include binge eating, starving, purging, chewing and spitting and over exercising.There are two less known eating disorders mdash night eating syndrome and orthorexia nervosamdash as well as further categories under the title of EDNOS , but today Irsquod Like to explore the three most common types of eating disorder.AnorexiaThe first case of anorexia was in  in France and the first paper on anorexia was written by Sir William Gull in .Anorexia is the relentless pursuit of low body weight either by curtailing food intake or restricting particular foods thought to be fattening. This can result in emaciation and the risk of collapse or death.Some people exercise compulsively to burn off the lsquoperceivedrsquo excess of calories from the small amount theydo manage to eat. The focus based on food is an attempt to cope with control and to feel some sense of power in their lives.It is not about simply wishing to be slim like models in magazines. Starvation causes the disorder to take control and this alters brain and body chemistry that results in further distortions, in thinking and emotional reasoning. As the illness takes more of a hold, a person starts to become exhausted as their energy levels are compromised due to lack of nutrition. This, together with an increase in negative energy, may account for the heaviness they feel.In all cases this heaviness is mistaken for fatness, hence they engage in a constant struggle to keep losing weight. It is a war on food that must be maintained despite the already severe weight loss that the person has incurred.Anorexia checklist:Weight loss in a short space of timeLoss of periods for womenFeeling cold all the timeDizzinessDry, rough, pale discoloured skinSevere restriction of foodFood rituals, such as chopping food into small pieces, counting bits of foodBloated stomach Loss of bone massMood swingsPerfectionistic attitudesInsecuritySelf-worth becomes based on what is eaten or not eatenIntense fear of gaining weightDistorted perception of body shape, weight, personality and amount of food eatenRigid and obsessive behaviourWearing baggy clothesAvoiding companyIn some cases some take laxativesBuzz from starving ndash sense of power or worthConviction that they are OK despite concerns of otherAs you can see, the above have far reaching effects on a personrsquos health and well-being, and as suchleft untreated can be fatal.The long term effects can lead to women becoming infertile or have dficulty getting pregnant. There is also a high risk of developing osteoporosis for both men and women.BulimiaThe term Bulimia nervosa literally means lsquoox hunger of nervous originrsquo. This hunger is driven by an emotional need that food cannot alone fill. Usually this person feels this void or gap or emptiness and they seek to use food to fill it. Unfortunately, as many find out, the emptiness cannot be filled by food, as it is emotional, physical and spiritual.Sufferers characteristically binge eat or over eat and end up feeling bloated, worse, too full. After their eating episode they then vomit and or take laxatives in a bid to prevent themselves from gaining weight. Others also over exercise in a bid to burn unwanted calories. As with anorexia, control and the abuse of food to cope are also present.Bulimia usually follows dieting and starts later than anorexia mdash in late adolescence. It may follow anorexia. It can continue for many yearsleft untreated, thus many older women have the illness. The period after childbirth is another time when women are at risk.Bulimia is also associated with low self esteem, lack of confidence and over-evaluation of weight and shape, and a need to control weight. Bulimic behaviour is very addictive as, while vomiting and exercising the brain releases endorphins, chemicals which are the bodyrsquos natural pain killers.The ritual confers a sense of emotional release, so what starts off as a way of controlling calories, becomes a way of getting this emotional release ndash which will be repeated whenever a person feels emotional or physical stress.Bulimia checklist:Frequent weight changes.Sore throat, swollen glands, tooth decay, bad breath.Preoccupation with an overestimation of body shape and weight.VomitingLaxative abuseRigid and harsh exercise regimesFear of putting on weightDepressionMood swingsElectrolyte and fluid imbalancesPoor skin condition and hair lossLethargy and tirednessHeart palpitationsInternal organs damageUncontrollable urges to eat vast amounts of foodAnxiety, guilt and shame attached to self and behaviourFeelings of isolationBuzz from vomiting, sense of release reliefBuzz from perceived weight lossEasy weight gain.Again, like anorexia, the above can have a far reaching effect on mental, emotional, physical and spiritual well being. In extreme cases bulimia causes heart failure because when a person induces vomiting, they lose potassium from the body.Potassium is a mineral which regulates the sdrenal glands, the nervous system, the heart and energy levels of the body. The adrenal glands in the body are responsible for handling stress effectively. Other dangers include rupture of the stomach, choking, drying up of saliy glands.Binge eatingLike bulimia, binge eating disorder has only recently been recognised as a distinct condition. It was in  that it was first acknowledged as an eating disorder in its own right.BED is very similar to bulimia in all respects, except that the person does not purge to dispose of unwanted calories. It is believed that there are more people suffering from BED than anorexia or bulimia.People who binge or overeat and who do not purge usually struggle with their weight, although not all are overweight. Being overweight , of course brings with it the risk of a host of other physical illnesses and most sufferers feel depressed, out of control and ashamed of their behaviour.Binge eating checklist:Binging in secretEating very rapidlyEmotional eatingCanrsquot stop when had enoughSensing the eating behaviour is not normalEating despite feeling very fullsometimesFeeling out of control when eatingShame, depression, guiltCompulsive eating when not hungryFantasies about being a better person when thin.As many people with weight issues are judged by society, a supportive and nurturing environment is necessary in order for the inidual to feel safe. Here again, education is a vital component of recovery from any eating disorder. Therapeutic interventions work at both physical and emotional levels to deal with the urges, cravings, to change eating habits, look at thought patterns and rules, becoming more emotionally resilient. Ultimately treatment is available that helps each inidual become empowered, recover and move forward with their lives.If you have any queries or would like to arrange an appointment please call   or email empower@post www.empowercounsellingni.prettyPhoto

title: Top dancer Anna qualifies for World Championships
story: LOCAL Irish dancers have proven themselves to be a step above the rest once again.Members of the Crossgar-based Scoil Rince an Chroiacute dance school enjoyed plenty of success at the Kelly Hendry Feis in Newcastle upon Tyne and the Mid-Ulster Grades Feis in Dungannon.Thirty-five dancers from the school took to the stage at both locations with dancers excelling in both the grades system and championships.The school ed home with  first places,  top five places and a host of trophies and sashes.The schoolrsquos success comes of the back of a very successful Ulster Championships in Ballybofey in October.Anna McGlew qualied for the World Championships to be held in Belfast at Easter and Sean Gordon achieved fth place, reaching a podium place at his first Ulsters, having only started to compete four months prior.Teacher Briacuted McKinney said: ldquoWhilst acknowledging the ious pandemic-related challenges brought to us in  and early this year, the great class spirit and support for each other helped drive our ious success both last year and this year to date.Co-teacher Maura Davidson commented: ldquoThe results are down to the commitment, dedication and support from our dancers and families.The school now prepares for their first championship feis in Downpatrick later this month and the World Championships at Easter.Classes continue weekly at the studio in Crossgar. For further information contact  ..prettyPhoto

title: pleas for help as cost of heating oil doubles
story: Price of petrol and diesel in Northern Ireland heading towards £ a litre   Sir Jeffrey Donaldson: No business as usual for Executive until protocol resolvedNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsNationalPrice of home heating oil in Northern Ireland doubles in less than a fortnightIn less than a fortnight the price of a litre of heating oil has doubled for NI consumers, prompting a plea to the Treasury to come to the aid of struggling families.By Graeme CousinsTuesday, th March , : pmUpdated Wednesday, th March , : am  "       "  Petrol and diesel costs are also spiralling upwards on a daily basis, and coupled with a succession of gas price rises, it means the cost of living crisis is impacting every single householder and motorist in the ProvinceAccording to price comparison website Cheapest Oil, the price of a litre of heating oil in Northern Ireland has risen from .p on February  to .p per litre yesterday – a near % increase in  days.Just last Wednesday the average cost of  litres of oil was £.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Home heating oil prices are rising steeply across Northern IrelandLast night it had reached £,.The dearest price being charged for heating oil in the Province as of yesterday evening was £, for  litres, £ for  litres and £ for  litres.Petrol and diesel has risen dramatically with £. per litre of fuel being reported in some forecourts.The DUP’s Ian Paisley is one of a number of politicians asking the Government for help for struggling families. The North Antrim MP urged the Treasury to make a temporary cut to fuel duty and VAT to help motorists in NI who he said are paying £ per week just to drive to and from work.The North Antrim MP said: “Within a rural area like Northern Ireland, many who work in our schools, hospitals and manufacturing have no access to public transport and depend on their car.”He said: “Party leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson has written to Chancellor with serious proposals which would help working families. It is time for the Government to step up and address a problem which has been predicted for weeks.”Other proposals made by the DUP include cancelling the planned .% increase in National Insurance contributions and offering targeted extra support to households in greatest need.UUP leader Doug Beattie has written to Foreign Secretary Liz Truss and European Commission Vice President Maros Sefcovic asking for immediate action to bring about a reduction in VAT on energy costs across the United Kingdom.He said: “If this can be done, it will give the most vulnerable hope that we can get through this present crisis which will help the material and societal wellbeing of the people of Northern Ireland.”He added: “I am extremely concerned that energy prices are soaring exponentially throughout the United Kingdom creating real societal dficulty.”Sinn Fein leader Michelle O’Neill said the Tory government must do more support workers and families struggling with cost of living.She also blamed the DUP for “walking away” from the Executive thus preventing a budget from being set while also preventing ministers from taking further action. In a letter to PM Boris Johnson, Ms O’Neill called on the British government to abandon its plans to hike people’s taxes from April and to introduce a windfall tax on high-profiting energy companies.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdown having a major impact on many of our advertisers — and consequently the revenue we receive — we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletter and enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. Visit https:www.newsletter subscriptions now to sign up.Our journalism costs money and we rely on advertising, print and digital revenues to help to support them. By supporting us, we are able to support you in providing trusted, fact-checked content for this website.Ben LowryEditor

title: wearing masks in school is of no benefit to children but rather causes harm
story: Where to drop off items in Northern Ireland to help refugees who are fleeing Ukraine   ‘Major rally’ details announced as unionists voice regret at Sinn Fein anonymity rulingNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionWearing masks in school is of no benefit to children but rather causes harmA letter from Hugh McCarthy:By LettersThursday, rd March , : amUpdated Thursday, rd March , : am  "       "  A school pupil’s capacity to express feelings is affected by being masked. Non-verbal communication with teachers is lostWhy are Northern Ireland school children still wearing masks Now that the English, Welsh and Scottish governments have dropped the requirement for schoolchildren to wear masks and it is optional in the Irish Republic, why are our children still strongly recommended to wear them in school This is plainly ridiculous.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The overwhelming body of scientic evidence shows that children are almost totally unaffected by the virus, whilst the evidence for the efficacy of masks has always been weak .What is indisputable is that wearing masks cause harm. Teaching, and hence learning, relies on communication, the essential verbal and non-verbal communication between child and teacher cannot take place behind a mask. All those non-verbal cues which teachers use to gauge understanding are being lost.A child’s capacity to express feelings and emotions is being affected by being masked. Some children cannot make eye contact and can’t sleep, clear signs of psychological distress and of course, impacting on their capacity to learn. Referrals to schools’ counselling services have rocketed.How can it be healthy for a child to wear a mask six or seven hours per day How can we justy a measure which has no benefit to children and accept the damage to their education, mental health and social development It is long past the time to end this abuse of our children.Hugh McCarthy, , Newtownabbey——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdowns having had a major impact on many of our advertisers — and consequently the revenue we receive — we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletter and enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. title: is this the best mural of footballing icon
story: United front from unionism for rescheduled anti-protocol rally   PSNI issue update on suspected abduction of young maleNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleNew George Best mural in east Belfast estate where the Northern Ireland and Manchester United legend grew upA new mural to George Best looks set to bring even more tourists to the estate where he grew up.By Graeme CousinsTuesday, th March , : pm  "       "  The mural, of the iconic footballer on international duty for Northern Ireland in , has been getting rave reviews since it was unveiled.It was painted on a gable wall in the Cregagh estate where Best grew up, and where fans of the player can also visit his childhood home.Last summer, the Best family home was retro-refurbished as a tourist attraction to look as it would have in  when a -year-old George Best left Belfast to follow his football dreams in Manchester.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.New mural to Manchester United and Northern Ireland international legend George Best in the Cregagh estate, east Belfast. Picture by Jonathan Porter PressEyeThe striking mural is the handiwork of Dee Craig from Belfast Mural Arts, who also recently painted a mural celebrating the history and heritage of Whitehead and another, in , at Aldergrove Flying Station to mark Captain Tom Moore’s th birthday.The mural overlooks Cregagh Green, the football pitch where Best’s talent first flourished as a schoolboy in the s.In , Belfast City Council signed a legal document pledging to protect the green space “in perpetuity”.Mr Craig was the first to share an image of the mural online saying: “George Best back at home, Cregagh Estate, Belfast.”Our Wee Country shared the same image and got a very good reaction from Northern Ireland fans.Ian Evans said: “That is absolutely fantastic, and thoroughly deserved – what a footballer.” Andrew Topley commented: “Fantastic likeness to George ... it’s a pity they didn’t include this artist in the making of that disastrous statue at National Stadium.”William Simpson said: “True likeness of George, beautul painted.”Norman McGladdery said that the artwork was befitting of the player who he said was “simply the best”.Neil Dylan Caldwell wrote: “No shortage of Vanand George Best murals to choose from in East Belfast. Incredible.”A statue of George Best was unveiled on his birthday on May ,  at Olympia leisure centre, next to Windsor Park while in  Belfast City Airport was renamed George Best City Airport in his honour.Best was a prodigy who went on to become one of the world’s greatest footballers of all time, a marauding presence with Manchester United and the Northern Ireland international team.He inspired the Old Trafford outfit to win two league titles and the European Cup in  while still a young player.But his career at United was cut short following a battle with alcohol, the pressures of stardom and global fame.He died on November ,  aged .——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
